summary: At least 2,000 outdated landline phone cables owned by AT&T, Verizon and other telecom giants are contaminating US soil and water with lead, which can cause brain damage, infertility and kidney failure. The cables are coated in lead, first used in the 1880s and phased out in the 1950s, and are believed to be responsible for the health and safety of children exposed to high levels. Tests revealed that more than 1,750 of the lead-sheathed cables were found underwater, and about 250 hang along streets and fields. The Wall Street Journal also reported that 80 percent of soil samples taken at sites near underwater cables had high lead levels. AT&W and Verizon responded by agreeing to spend up to $1.5 million to remove eight miles of toxic cables.
description: A new report found At least 2,000 outdated phone cables owned by AT&T, Verizon and other telecom giants could contaminate soil and water with lead and may have impacted children as young as six.

summary:
20 GOP attorneys general warn CVS, Walgreens against selling abortion pills. The big picture: Nearly a month after the FDA made a regulatory change allowing retail pharmacies to offer abortion pills, the attorneys general told the big pharmacy chains that selling mifepristone ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ which is used in medication abortions ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ is "unsafe and illegal," per a press release. ‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ The letter also noted that certain state laws prohibit the mailing and distribution of abortion pills. The Justice Department clarified in early January that the Comstock Act does not prohibit the mailing of abortion pills "where the sender lacks the intent that the recipient of the drugs will use them unlawfully."
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ The attorneys general argued against the DOJ's interpretation in the letter, saying that "the text, not the Biden administration's view, is what governs."
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ They warned CVS and Walgreens that "consequences for accepting the Biden administration's reading could come far sooner," adding that civil litigation against the companies could be brought by state attorneys general or private citizens.

Zoom out: At least 19 states have banned or severely restricted the use of telemedicine to access abortion pills, and instead require that patient get the medications from medical facilities in person.
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ There are currently two lawsuits that argue that states cannot regulate or restrict drugs that are FDA-approved.
description: The attorneys general said that CVS and Walgreen would be violating federal law if they distribute abortion pills.

summary:

Advocacy groups, including the Open Markets Institute and National Farmers Union, on Thursday asked U.S. antitrust enforcers to stop Kroger Co 's planned $25 billion purchase of rival grocery giant Albertsons Companies Inc.

 

"As organizations representing farmers, workers, consumers, and advocates for fair food systems, we urge the Federal Trade Commission to block Kroger's acquisition of Albertsons," the letter said. "Many Kroger and Albertsons store workers already struggle to meet their basic needs," they said, noting that a 2021 study of Kroger workers found that 75% had trouble buying groceries.

summary:

Among those carriers that have announced price limits are American, United, and Delta Air Lines, all of which said they would limit fares in all markets where Southwest operates, through Jan. 2. 

Google flight info shows one-way trips out of airports like Nashville International Airport, Ronald Reagan Washington International Airport, and Chicago Midway International Airport ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ all Southwest hubs ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ show prices surging over the next few days.

An American Airlines representative pointed NBC News to a tweet buried in response to a user saying select cities would see price caps.

summary: The Fed is trying to keep consumers from spending more because they are being forced to spend more due to rising prices and falling interest rates. Fed critics worry that policymakers are misdiagnosing the inflationary problem, and that consumers are spending more money now only because they built up savings when they could not spend money during the pandemic. The Fed's insistence on curbing the "inflationary pressure" of consumers being willing to spend "too much" is seen as a sign of weakness.

summary: Walgreens, Walmart and CVS are getting into the business of clinical trials, with their ubiquitous stores and troves of patient data. Walgreens and Walmart have both launched their own clinical trial programs, while CVS has done so in mid-2021. A new survey of more than 8,000 patients has found that 96 percent of those surveyed want their results immediately, even if a doctor hasn't reviewed them. summary:
Freight companies are preparing for what executives are calling a muted peak season, as dimming shipping demand from overstocked retailers ripples across U.S. shipping markets. 

Several big operators say they are seeing freight demand drop off rather than pick up heading into what is typically their busiest period of the year. 

DAT Solutions LLC, a load board that matches trucks to available loads, said its index for spot market demand fell sharply from August to September, to the lowest point since February. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫A large part of that is that we‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve seen inventory builds earlier in the year than we traditionally have seen because of all the supply-chain disruptions and the desire of a lot of retailers to get ahead of that.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Freight executives say demand remains solid by historical measures, suggesting shipping markets are reaching some equilibrium after sharp swings in business during the pandemic.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Rates are still up this year over last year,‚Äö√Ñ√π said Jeffrey Tucker, chief executive of Tucker Company Worldwide Inc., a Haddonfield, N.J.-based freight broker.
description: The outlook for a muted peak season comes as shipments and freight rates are already slipping.

summary: CNBC Daily Open brings investors up to speed on everything they need to know, no matter where they are. Monday's market moves were lukewarm, but regional banks managed to avoid losses amid renewed fears of banking instability. The Federal Reserve's most recent Financial Stability Report, published Monday, confirmed that one of respondents' biggest economic fears is "banking-sector stress." Other concerns about the economy, such as persistent inflation and tighter monetary policy, remain. The specter of the U.S. defaulting on its debt is likely to be seen when Congress fails to reach an agreement to raise the ceiling.
description: Markets made fractional moves Monday as banking turmoil, inflation worries and debt ceiling fears persist.

summary: Goldman Sachs (GS) disclosed in a filing from its parent company SVB Financial that it purchased a $1.8 billion loss from a securities sale that kicked off market panic about California lender Silicon Valley Bank last week. The disclosure reinforces the central role Goldman Sachs played in the final days of the nation‚Äôs 16th-largest bank, and Goldman was also the banker tapped to attempt a $2.25 billion capital raise last week for the bank as the lender wrestled with an outflow of deposits. On Tuesday it said in a new federal filing that the bank received approximately $21.45 billion for a portfolio of available for sale securities with a book value of approximately $23.97 billion. Goldman declined to comment.
description: The Wall Street giant purchased securities and attempted to raise capital as Silicon Valley Bank tried to survive, according to filings.

summary: BlackRock has submitted a preliminary prospectus for a spot-market bitcoin ETF, which has been repeatedly rejected by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. BlackRock's name, size and traditional finance background may go a long way toward overcoming the agency‚Äö√Ñ√¥s opposition to an inevitable development, and the SEC has been cracking down on the cryptocurrency industry. summary: EBay is making a change to the way shoppers buy products on its site, making many acquisitions to add to its power. The move comes after eBay acquired PayPal in 2002 and PayPal in 2004. summary: FedEx Corp. reported a drop in earnings for the second straight quarter due to a slowdown in shipping and higher shipping rates. The delivery company said that ongoing cost cuts and increased shipping rates led to improvements at its Ground and Freight divisions, while its Express unit struggled to cope with a decrease in shipping volumes.

summary: Unite Here Local 11, a union representing 32,000 workers in the industry in Southern California and Arizona, has walked out of four hotels, including two near Disneyland. The walkouts come after a three-day strike that hit hotels in downtown Los Angeles, Santa Monica and Orange County over the busy Fourth of July weekend. The union has proposed an immediate $5 hourly wage increase and a $3 boost annually for three years, but has yet to respond to this proposal. The Westin Bonaventure Hotel & Suites in downtown L.A., the union‚Äö√Ñ√¥s biggest employer, reached a tentative deal June 28 and is the only hotel that has averted a strike. No new bargaining sessions have been scheduled.
description: Workers at four more hotels, including two near Disneyland, walked off the job Tuesday, joining a second wave of strikes to hit Southern California's hospitality sector this summer.

summary: Shares of gas pipeline operator ONEOK Inc fell 9% on Monday due to concerns over potential synergies from its deal to acquire oil pipeline operator Magellan Midstream Partners. On Sunday, the company said it would pay $18.8 billion in cash and stock for Magellan to diversify its natural gas and gas-liquids transportation business into oil and oil products. Analysts said the potential value from the deal depends heavily on the impact on ONEOk's future tax liabilities, and the deal would build ONOEK's presence in top U.S. shale fields such as the Permian Basin and Bakken shale. U.N. gas producers last week slashed the number of drilling rigs by the most in seven years, in a sign of future weakness for gas-pipeline companies. ONEOke shares were trading at $58.17 on Monday, off 8.7%, while Magellan was up 14% at $63.17.
description: Shares of gas pipeline operator ONEOK Inc fell about 9% on Monday on questions about potential synergies from its deal to acquire oil pipeline operator Magellan Midstream Partners.  ONEOK on Sunday said it would pay $18.8 billion in cash and stock for Magellan to diversify its natural gas and gas-liquids transportation business into oil and oil products.  The businesses are quite distinct and the potential value from the deal depends heavily on the impact on ONEOK's future tax liabilities, analysts said.

summary: The United States is seeking to sustain its liquefied natural gas exports to Europe, while promoting efforts to fight global warming. The United States has become the world‚Äö√Ñ√¥s top gas producer in recent years, and competes with Qatar to be top LNG exporter. A credible market for certified natural gas could help it tackle both goals at once, and a lack of unified standards on measuring and verifying emissions across the gas supply chain has prevented low-carbon gas markets from taking off. The administration is also hosting a private meeting on certified gas at the CERAWeek energy conference in Houston with about 20 speakers.
description: The Biden administration is holding talks with global energy companies and foreign officials in an effort to set standards for certified natural gas, a form of the fuel that producers market as climate friendly.  The effort comes as the United States seeks to sustain its liquefied natural gas, or LNG, exports to Europe to displace Russian fuel, while also promoting efforts to fight global warming.  A credible market for certified natural gas could help it tackle both goals at once.

summary: Tiffany Bova's book The Experience Mindset explains how an increased focus on EX can magnify company growth many times over. summary: Xcel Energy has reported that small amounts of tritium may have reached the Mississippi River following a leak at its Monticello plant late last year. The leak raised questions about public safety and transparency, but industry experts said there was never a public health threat. Following the leak, Xcel has been working with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Minnesota Department of Health and Minnesota Pollution Control Agency to monitor groundwater in the area for tritiam. The closest water sample to detect tritsium is about 30 feet from the river and is far below Safe Drinking Water Act standards, at 1,000 picocuries per liter. Xcel says that it has pumped nearly 3 million gallons of groundwater for storage and reuse, and has recovered over three-quarters of the tritum that was released.
description: Tritium occurs naturally in the environment and is a common by-product of nuclear plant operations.

summary:
Centene‚Äö√Ñ√¥s net profits rose to $738 million, or $1.27 per share, in the third quarter ended Sept. 30 compared to $584 million, or 99 cents per share in the year ago period. 

Meanwhile, Centene‚Äö√Ñ√¥s third quarter revenues increased 11% to $35.9 billion from $32.4 billion in the year-ago quarter thanks to to growth of sales and membership in its Medicaid and Medicare plans. Centene, which sells an array of government subsidized health insurance including Obamacare, said total managed care membership increased to 26.8 million compared to 25.6 million in the year-ago period. 

"Our strong third quarter and year-to-date results provide Centene with positive momentum as we move towards 2023," said Sarah London, Centene‚Äö√Ñ√¥s chief executive officer, who Tuesday announced her decision to once again raise the company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s full-year adjusted earnings per share outlook for the rest of the year.

summary:

On a December call with analysts, Nike executives downplayed the severity of the inventory bloat, noting strong demand for Nike products and residual impact of the supply chain snarls that dinged most retailers in recent years. 

But Nike's China sales in the fiscal year that ended May 31 decreased 9% to $7.5 billion.

summary: Steve Eisman, the money manager who famously bet against frothy US mortgages before the housing bubble burst in 2008, now sees value in a different type of American spending: infrastructure. summary: A survey of some banks and credit unions in Texas and parts of Louisiana and New Mexico has revealed that lending conditions and terms for loans have tightened, with marked rises in loan pricing. summary: An electric vehicle abruptly stopped in the middle of a busy road near Salisbury, England, and remained immovable for most of the day, causing a nine-hour traffic bottleneck. A team of workers was unable to move the stranded EV because ‚Äö√Ñ√∫the handbrakes of electric cars, and some other modern cars, are controlled electronically, unlike those of traditional petrol and diesel cars which are mechanical. This is yet another damning anecdote spotlighting the drawbacks of electric vehicles, which have been touted as the superior alternative to gas-powered cars. summary: Banks are getting stingy with commercial property mortgages, with the CBRE Lending Momentum Index falling 54% in the first quarter of 2023 compared with a year ago. summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 22% drop in revenue for the April-June period, with the world's largest maker of memory chips expecting to slide by 22% to 60 trillion won. summary:

Oct 7 (Reuters) - Medical device-maker Becton Dickinson & Co has issued a voluntary recall of 17 versions of its sterilization containers, according to a Wall Street Journal report on Friday citing a company letter to customers sent this week. 

The reusable containers, which are sold under the brand name Genesis Sterrad, are used by hospitals for storing surgical instruments before and after sterilization. 

The company, according to the WSJ report, said the containers have not "consistently met testing requirements" for a type of quality test known as aerosol challenge, in which they are exposed to aerosol particles to check whether they enter the container.

The automaker said it sold 1.85 million cars and light trucks in the United States last year, as well as 13,539 heavy trucks.

summary: UnitedHealthcare will soon implement a prior authorization policy for surveillance and diagnostic colonoscopies, which requires pre-approval from the insurer. This policy does not apply to screening colonoscopy, which is the routine procedure generally conducted once every ten years to examine the large intestine for ulcers, polyps, and cancer in low-risk members of the general population between the ages of 45 and 74. The policy is controversial as it goes against the grain of what experts in the field would consider a rational pathway. However, it is cost-effective for patients at high risk for developing colorectal cancer, and Medicare had a somewhat analogous coverage policy which was heavily criticized and subsequently reversed.
description: On June 1st, UnitedHealthcare will implement a controversial prior authorization policy for surveillance and diagnostic colonoscopies.

summary: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has issued a Class I recall for 348,616 Medtronic Defibrillators, saying serious injury or death may occur from a flaw in the device. The recall includes Medtronics's Implantable Cardioverter Defibrilators (ICDs) and Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy Defibrillsators (CRT-Ds) with glassed feedthrough sold between Oct. 13, 2017, to June 9, 2023. The FDA has sent its customers the following required actions for software issues related to the recall, including not prophylactically replace devices for this issue. Customers with questions should contact Medtron at 1-800-929-4043.

summary:

Migrant workers are reportedly securing more job opportunities with better pay and conditions as US employers scramble to keep their businesses humming despite historically tight labor conditions. US employers had approximately 11 million job vacancies in December, compared to just 5.7 million people who were looking for work, according to federal data. The labor market has remained tight despite the Federal Reserve‚Äö√Ñ√¥s ongoing series of interest rate hikes, which are meant to cool the economy and bring down inflation that surged to its highest level in decades last year.

summary:
Mullan has worked at the Hilton for almost 35 years, having helped to run hotels all across the world, including in Egypt, Barbados, Malta and Abu Dhabi. Its general manager, Peter Avis, began his career in hospitality as a dishwasher in Miami at only 17, having moved to the US from his home town of Liverpool.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫I didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have any formal education, and I was told by my school that I should go and get a job with the council and sweep the streets,‚Äö√Ñ√π Avis says. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫But when I was 17, my sister got a modelling contract in Miami, and I got the chance to go out there with her for three weeks and decided to stay there. 

From there, Avis worked at an array of hotels and restaurants before taking up his role at Windows in 2020. His biggest challenge since then has been the current staff shortage ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ experienced hospitality workers have been in short supply since European workers went home during the coronavirus pandemic and were discouraged from returning by Brexit.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫There‚Äö√Ñ√¥s a hole in the workforce, and there is a crisis in hospitality recruitment,‚Äö√Ñ√π Avis says.
description: A look behind the scenes at one of London‚Äö√Ñ√¥s most celebrated hotels

summary: Ford is recalling 422,000 SUVs in the U.S. due to a rear camera malfunction that may keep the image from displaying properly. The recall covers 2020-2023 Ford Explorers and Lincoln Aviators, as well as 2020-2122 model year Lincoln Corsairs. Ford received 17 reports of minor crashes and more than 2,100 warranty reports linked to the recall. The company is working with suppliers to identify what is causing the issue and provide a fix. Dealers will notify vehicle owners about a fix starting July 5 to replace the steering wheel wiring for free.
description: Ford is recalling over 400,000 SUVs over a serious malfunction impacting their rear-view cameras

summary: Omnicom Group Inc. is set to significantly reduce its real-estate footprint and formalize return-to-office requirements for all U.S. employees. The company expects growth to continue through 2023, and will require all employees to return to the office at least three days per week. This indicates that marketers' continued spending will help the advertising giant largely avoid the economic headwinds that have hit the tech and finance industries.
description: The owner of ad agencies including BBDO and TBWA predicts continued growth throughout 2023 as clients spend on performance- and event-based marketing services.

summary: The senators had done their homework‚Äö√Ñ√Æor maybe it happens to be that there are a lot of Taylor Swift fans in the Senate, which turned its attention this week toward figuring out what went so wrong when the singer-songwriter attempted to sell tickets to her highly anticipated Eras Tour. And then there was his most obscure reference‚Äö√Ñ√Æa bit more of a taunt directed at Joe Berchtold, the Live Nation president and chief financial officer who testified on behalf of the entertainment behemoth. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫I have to throw out, in deference to my daughter Eliza, one more Taylor Swift quote,‚Äö√Ñ√π Lee said. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫You leverage market power in one market to get market power in another market‚Äö√Ñ√Æand it looks like you‚Äö√Ñ√¥re doing that in, frankly, multiple markets.‚Äö√Ñ√π Barack Obama‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Department of Justice approved the merger between industry stalwart Ticketmaster and management and promotion heavyweight Live Nation in 2010, it anticipated issues related to the company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s outsize market share, and placed the company under a consent decree that aimed to restrict the types of deals it could make.
description: After a sales fiasco over Taylor Swift‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Eras Tour, senators reamed out Live Nation and Ticketmaster, which merged in 2010, for acting like a monopoly. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Ticketmaster ought to look in the mirror and say, ‚Äö√Ñ√≤I‚Äö√Ñ√¥m the problem, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s me,‚Äö√Ñ√¥‚Äö√Ñ√π Senator Richard Blumenthal said.

summary: General Mills, maker of Cheerios and other cereals, reported a 1.17% drop in sales in its most recently completed quarter due to weak volumes and retailers trim inventories. The company's top line rose 3%, boosted again by higher prices that food makers have been using for more than a year to pass through higher costs to consumers, while volumes fell 6%, with the biggest drop-offs seen in its international and North American retail markets. General Mills is expecting adjusted earnings to rise 4% to 6%, and its pet-food business was a bright spot during the quarter, with higher prices driving revenue up 7%. The company also sold more dry pet food and dog treats, though wet pet food sales were down.
description: The maker of Cheerios and Bisquick pancake mix said its top line rose 3%, boosted by higher prices.

summary: First Solar (FSLR) closed at $219.48 in the latest trading session, marking a +0.27% move from the previous day. This move outpaced the S&P 500's daily gain of 0.09%. Wall Street will be looking for positivity from First Solar as it approaches its next earnings report date, which is expected to be April 27, 2023. The company is projected to report earnings of $1.08 per share, which would represent year-over-year growth of 363.41%. The Zacks Industry Rank gauges the strength of individual industry groups by measuring the average Zacks Rank of the individual stocks within the groups.
description: First Solar (FSLR) closed at $219.48 in the latest trading session, marking a +0.27% move from the prior day.

summary: Thirty-four Tyson Foods employees, former employees and family members have filed a lawsuit against the company for failing to take appropriate precautions during the early days of the COVID pandemic. The lawsuit claims Tyson knew about COVID as early as January 2020, when the virus was spreading through its facilities in China. At least 59,000 meat-packing workers contracted COVID-19 and 269 workers died in 2020. Tyson also didn't provide masks or allow work modifications to allow for social distancing until late April 2020, and didn't perform contact tracing or quarantine infected workers. The case has been sent back to Iowa state court.
description: Thirty-four Tyson Foods employees, former employees and family members have filed a lawsuit against the company.

summary: US firms have sold $55 billion of secured notes in the junk-bond market so far in 2023, marking a 17% year-over-year increase. This is the biggest issuance jump in more than a decade and an indication that companies are replacing floating-rate debt in the wake of the Federal Reserve‚Äö√Ñ√¥s most-aggressive monetary tightening cycle in decades. The fallout from higher interest rates is rippling into other types of deals, from corporate loan refinancing to leveraged buyouts. The year's sparse issuance of new loans has helped spur a small resurgence in demand from investors, but it remains unclear how long a resurgence in debt can last.
description: The high-yield bond market is becoming a favorite of companies that once raised cash using leveraged loans, luring borrowers with lower costs and a wealth of investor demand.

summary: Bank of America, the nation's second largest bank, has seen an inflow of more than $15 billion worth of deposits following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank last week. Other large-scale lenders like JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo have also seen substantial increases in deposits, though the exact figures have yet to be publicized. On Wednesday, shares of Credit Suisse dropped to near-record lows after its largest stakeholder said he would not bolster his investment in the Swiss banking giant. The banking sector as a whole appears poised to absorb losses on Wednesday, with shares of Bank of America down 2.9% while Morgan Stanley‚Äôs stock dipped 3.2%.
description: The mass migration to Bank of America, the nation‚Äôs second largest, comes in the wake of the swift collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature.

summary: The US Treasury Secretary has announced that customers of collapsed Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank will receive a full return of their lost deposits, using a single exception to banking law that otherwise caps protection for cash and cash equivalent deposits at $250,000. The exception, known as the Systematic Risk Exemption (SRE), is a caveat in the 1991 Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Improvement Act (FDICIA). This week's measures differ significantly from the controversial backstops that taxpayers were asked to shoulder in the 2008 financial crisis, when FDIC funds alone proved too minimal to cover SREs that the Bush administration authorized to rescue some of the nation's largest banks. Critics have criticized the measure as an unfair use of banking law, and ultimately, as a government bailout.
description: Silicon Valley Bank's deposits were backstopped by the government over the weekend, a move made possible by a narrow legal exception inside a 32-year-old banking law.

summary: The Supreme Judicial Court of Middlesex Superior Court ruled Tuesday that Patricia Walsh Greene, a Newton woman who developed brain cancer from smoking Marlboro Lights cigarettes, is owed $37 million by Philip Morris USA Co. The SJC ruled that Greene fell victim to the tobacco company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s ‚Äö√Ñ√∫smoke screen‚Äö√Ñ√π that falsely claimed the brand was safer to smoke than Marlborough Red. The jury awarded Greene $6.5 million for past and future pain and suffering and $2.6 million for medical costs, and awarded her husband Frederick Douglas Greene, $500,000 for loss of consortium. Following a four-week trial, the jury voted in Greene's favor and concluded that Philip MorrisUSA had engaged in a civil conspiracy with other tobacco companies dating back to the 1950s when top executives met and agreed to launch a decades long marketing campaign falsely claiming cigarette smoking was not harmful.
description: A Newton woman who developed brain cancer from smoking Marlboro Lights cigarettes is owed $37 million by Philip Morris USA Co. after the state‚Äö√Ñ√¥s high court ruled Tuesday she fell victim to the tobacco company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s ‚Äö√Ñ√∫smoke screen‚Äö√Ñ√π that falsely claimed the brand was safer to smoke than Marlboro Red.

summary: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has issued a slow-down on Norfolk Southern's plans to dispose of waste from the East Palestine, Ohio train derailment until it can review the process. Officials in Michigan and Texas have complained after receiving shipments of toxic waste with little warning to local officials, leading to frustration from local officials. The EPA says Norfolk Southern had previously been responsible for the plans, but the EPA has taken over that process. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg personally visited the site last week, but many critics argued the visit came too late, with nearly three weeks passing since the Feb. 3 crash. Buttigigieg said he had tried to balance his desire to get involved with the "norm of transportation secretaries" and that he felt strongly about the situation.
description: President Biden's administration has ordered a slow-down on removal of toxic waste from the East Palestine, Ohio train derailment, arguing the EPA must review the process.

summary: Norfolk Southern Corporation President and CEO Alan Shaw testifies before the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee on March 9. This is the third such incident since early February, and has put a spotlight on the company and left residents of East Palestine concerned about the safety of their air and water. Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse interrupted testimony from Norfolk Southern CEO Shaw before a hearing of the Senate Senate Environment & Public Works committee to tell him of the derailment. Norfolk Southern said in a statement that there were no injuries and "no reports of a hazardous materials release."
description: The incident follows two Norfolk Southern train derailments in Ohio.

summary: The US National Transportation Safety Board has announced that it will conduct a special investigation into rail company Norfolk Southern's safety practices and culture following the recent derailments of its trains. The NTSB has urged the company to take immediate action to review and assess its safety practices, with the input of employees and others, and implement necessary changes to improve safety. The company has been under fire since early February after a train carrying hazardous materials derailed in East Palestine, Ohio. The Ohio train derailment made national headlines after hazardous vinyl chloride gas in some of the cars was vented and burned to prevent an explosion. Residents of the village and surrounding areas have been worried since the derailment that the burned gas will cause health problems and pollute the region's water and ground.
description: The US National Transportation Safety Board announced it will conduct a special investigation into rail company Norfolk Southern's safety practices and culture following the recent derailments of its trains.

summary: The National Transportation Safety Board has announced a special investigation into rail operator Norfolk Southern following a fiery derailment on the Ohio-Pennsylvania border in February and several other accidents, including the death of a train conductor just hours earlier on Tuesday. The agency is urging the company to take immediate action to review and assess its safety practices, and has announced plans to improve the use of detectors placed along railroad tracks to spot overheating bearings and other problems in response to the derailment in Ohio last month. The NTSB has said the crew operating the train that derailed 3 February got a warning from such a detector but couldn‚Äôt stop the train before more than three dozen cars came off the tracks and caught fire. The past pattern of railroads resisting safety regulations must change and that Congress should support the effort to improve safety.
description: National Transportation Safety Board will look into five significant accidents involving the operator since December 2021

summary: A Norfolk Southern conductor was fatally struck by a dump truck in Cleveland Tuesday morning, the third incident involving a Norfolk Southern train in Ohio in just over a month. The company is under increased scrutiny as its CEO prepares to testify before the Senate on railway safety. This week, Norfolk Southern announced a new plan to ‚Äúimmediately enhance the safety of its operations,‚Äù including initiatives to detect overheated wheel bearings. The bill proposed by a group of Democratic and Republican senators would enhance safety procedures for trains that carry hazardous material, increase fines on rail lines for safety violations and require trains to operate with two-person crews.
description: The collision comes three days after a Norfolk Southern train derailed in western Ohio, and just over a month after another derailment that caused a chemical leak in eastern Ohio.

summary: The National Transportation Safety Board has opened an investigation into Norfolk Southern Railway's safety practices and culture in response to five "significant" accidents dating back to December 2021. The NTSB is concerned that several "organizational factors" may have been involved in the accidents, including "safety culture." The company is also looking into an Oct. 8, 2021 incident in which an employee for the National Salvage and Service Corporation died while working with Norfolk Southern in Reed, Pennsylvania to replace a track and the operator of a spike machine reversed direction and struck the employee. Norfolk Southern CEO Alan Shaw said the company is "going to rebuild our safety culture from the ground up" and that it will not continue.
description: The special investigation comes after a conductor was killed during a collision Tuesday.

summary: Federal investigators on Tuesday announced a special investigation into rail operator Norfolk Southern following a fiery derailment on the Ohio-Pennsylvania border in February and several other accidents, including the death of a train conductor this week. The National Transportation Safety Board has sent investigation teams to look into five significant accidents involving Norfolk Southern since December 2021. The agency also said it was urging the company to take immediate action to review and assess its safety practices. Norfolk Southern announced plans on Monday to improve the use of detectors placed along railroad tracks to spot overheating bearings and other problems in response to the derailment in Ohio a month ago. Government officials say tests haven't found dangerous levels of chemicals in the air or water in the area.
description: The National Transportation Safety Board says it will begin a broad look at rail operator Norfolk Southern's safety culture, saying it has sent investigation teams to look into five significant accidents involving Norfolk Southern since December 2021.

summary: A Norfolk Southern conductor was fatally struck by a dump truck in Cleveland Tuesday morning, the third incident involving a Norfolk Southern train in Ohio in just over a month. The company is under increased scrutiny as its CEO prepares to testify before the Senate on railway safety. This week, Norfolk Southern announced a new plan to ‚Äúimmediately enhance the safety of its operations,‚Äù including initiatives to detect overheated wheel bearings. The bill proposed by a group of Democratic and Republican senators would enhance safety procedures for trains that carry hazardous material, increase fines on rail lines for safety violations and require trains to operate with two-person crews.
description: The collision comes three days after a Norfolk Southern train derailed in western Ohio, and just over a month after another derailment that caused a chemical leak in eastern Ohio.

summary: Home builders are doing better than many investors expected, and better than they were in the fall, due to high interest rates and the shortage of available real estate. After hitting a multidecade low of about 2.7% in early 2021, the average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage is now around 6.7%. This has effectively stuck a lot of people in their homes, and the supply of previously owned, or existing, homes for sale has dwindled. Even at higher rates there are still people who want to buy a home, and some can buy in cash. This has implications for the economy, too, as it is beginning to look as if the residential investment component of gross domestic product might have swung into positive territory this quarter for the first time since the first quarter of 2021.
description: The low supply of available homes is giving builders ample reason to step up construction, despite high interest rates.

summary: A new cruise guest asked on Reddit if tourists had any ‚Äö√Ñ√≤unusual‚Äö√Ñ√π items they pack for a cruise. One guest said they always packed a special machine to help them get a ‚Äö√Ñ√∫restful sleep‚Äö√Ñ√π and that they always brought a white noise machine to drown out creaking/weather/neighbours. Cruise ships can be noisy at night, but guests should check their cruise line‚Äö√Ñ√¥s rules before packing an electronic item as some are banned for safety reasons. Other guests share tips on how to save money on a holiday, such as bringing clothes pegs on a cruise holiday to protect their swimming costumes, and checking the right clothes for each place.
description: Packing for a cruise can be a struggle. Experienced cruise guests have shared the "unusual" items that passengers might not want to forget.

summary: Apple's Taiwan suppliers saw revenue fall for a fourth straight month in May, due to high living costs and a slowdown in consumer discretionary spending. The group of device assemblers like Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. and components makers like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. reported overall sales of NT$944.10 billion ($30.5 billion) in May. The Mac division was especially hard hit by the wider slowdown in demand for personal computers, falling 31% in the first quarter. In the smartphone market, Apple is showing greater resilience than rivals, many of which have recorded double-digit declines in shipments as unsold inventory is being cleared through.
description: (Bloomberg) -- Revenue among Taiwan‚Äö√Ñ√¥s major Apple Inc. suppliers fell for a fourth straight month in May, as high living costs keep a lid on consumer discretionary spending.Most Read from BloombergThese Are World‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Most Expensive Cities for High-Class LivingHedging Failure Exposes Private Equity to Interest-Rate SurgeWhat We Know About the Missing Titanic SubmersibleTitanic Explorer Says Two Likely Disaster Causes Are Survivable. One Is NotAlibaba Names Tsai Chairman, Wu CEO in Surprise Shake-Up

summary:
EXCLUSIVE Boeing shores up Defense unit leadership after delays. 

Addressing the nuts and bolts of BDS is significant not only because of immediate pressures but because its work on advanced new design methods is expected to shape future civil jetliner programs at Boeing Commercial Airplanes (BCA). In 2006, incoming BCA chief Scott Carson appointed Jim Jamieson chief operating officer of the planemaking unit - a wide brief giving him effective oversight of jet manufacturing and development until his retirement about 18 months later.

Jamieson's manufacturing muscle was seen at the time as a counterweight to Carson's sales and financial background after the departure of revered jetliner chief Alan Mulally to Ford.

Those changes came just as Boeing was trying to juggle changes in manufacturing with the development of the Boeing 787, while still bearing the wounds of a 1997 production crisis.

Boeing is once again involved in a radical overhaul of design and manufacturing methods, using digital modelling rooted in the development of the T-7A military trainer. Boeing has deferred a possible decision on launching a pair of new civil jets by around two years amid debts and questions over the timing of new production systems and engine technology.
description: Boeing Co has appointed a senior troubleshooter to help turn around loss-making programs at its Defense, Space & Security (BDS) division in what some sources view as a potential template for future efforts to fix wider industrial woes.

summary: At the Paris Air Show, manufacturers and airlines returned to form after a four-year hiatus, with orders running into the hundreds. The stretched version of the Airbus SE A220 is a model that would expand Airbus‚Äö√Ñ√¥s smallest jet family to three versions, keeping with the rising popularity of longer aircraft that have more capacity. However, Pratt & Whitney engines powering the Airbus A320neo as well as the A220 have grappled with durability issues, and Airbus is also busy lifting output on its A320 family aircraft to meet surging demand. The current Pratt and Whitney engine is maxed out at 24,000 pounds of thrust thrust thrust, while the larger version for the A320 is too large for too large. Airbus is looking to bring the stretched A220 to market quickly and accept that it will take as long as possible to make more A320s.
description: At the Paris Air Show, manufacturers and airlines returned to form after a four-year hiatus, with a flurry of orders that ran into the hundreds on the first two days.

summary: Aviation executives are calling on European leaders to pitch in more taxpayer funding to clean up emissions, as they fear that the region risks falling behind the US where subsidies have jump-started funding for fossil-fuel alternatives. The EU is mandating use of at least 6% biofuels and e-fuels in commercial aircraft by 2030, rising to 34% by 2040. Airlines are using the industry‚Äôs biggest annual gathering to press the case for Europe to emulate the US and pour money into the sector, while environmentalists have countered that people should fly less to cut back on CO2 emissions. French President Emmanuel Macron said France will help fund a ‚Ç¨1 billion ($1.1 billion) plant to produce sustainable aviation fuel, which is just a trickle of the estimated $1.45 trillion needed to fund the global clean-fuel push, a linchpin of the industry's goal of reducing carbon emissions to net-zero by 2050. Earlier on Friday, Emirates Airline President Tim Clark warned from the stage that Dutch efforts to limit flights at the country's Amsterdam hub and France's banning of a handful of flights have the potential to get a ‚Äúhead of steam‚Äù restricting airline capacity.
description: Aviation executives implored European leaders to pitch in more taxpayer funding to clean up emissions, warning that the region risks falling behind the US, where subsidies have jump-started funding for fossil-fuel alternatives.

summary: This article highlights the importance of using popular efficiency ratios to determine a company's potential to make profits. These ratios measure the ability to transform available input into output and provide stellar returns. Examples of these ratios include Deere & Company, Tecnoglass TGLS and Thermon THR. These stocks have an average four-quarter positive earnings surprise of 4.7%. The article also highlights the potential for investors to benefit from the increased stock market.

summary:
Resort fees are often hidden. Critics say the fees have little to do with the amenities provided, pointing to the fact that many hotels continued to change a resort fee when most amenities were shut down due to the coronavirus. 

Following an investigation into resort fees by 50 state attorneys general, the D.C. attorney general‚Äö√Ñ√¥s office sued Marriott over the practice in 2019, while the Nebraska attorney general‚Äö√Ñ√¥s office sued Hilton. Marriott reached a settlement with the Pennsylvania attorney general‚Äö√Ñ√¥s office in 2021 in which it agreed to disclose resort fees on the first page of its booking process as part of the total advertised price.
description: The often-hidden charges hotels tack on to their rates are getting a look from the White House as part of its effort to crack down on "junk" fees.

summary: The current economy is characterized by an interesting mix of optimism and anxiety, with franchise growth expected to continue. However, rising interest rates are impacting franchise growth and expansion outlook. Franchises show unique characteristics in response to economic fluctuations and tend to exhibit counter-cyclical behavior, often performing better during challenging times. The International Franchise Association forecasted that franchises in the U.S. would grow by 3.0% in 2023, adding 254,000 jobs, reaching a total of 8.7 million employees. With franchise opportunities growing across various industries, it is crucial to recognize the number of economic factors playing a role in the overall success. The SBA's role in facilitating capital access for small businesses, including franchises, is crucial.
description: Franchises are a significant segment of the economy and despite a challenging economic environment, growth is expected to continue.

The company has nearly 4 million natural gas customers and 500,000 electric customers in six states. NiSource derives substantially all of its revenues and earnings from the operating results of these rate-regulated utilities. NI shares are a component of the S&P 500.

summary: Plant-based plastics, or bioplastics, have accounted for just 1% of the world‚Äö√Ñ√¥s plastic production for well over a decade. Their production is now growing 14% a year, and they are expected to reach 3% in the next five years. BioplastICS are usually derived from plants rich in starch, sugar or pulp, such as corn, wheat, sugar cane, wood and cotton, which make them costlier than plastics made from fossil fuels. They absorb carbon dioxide, which cuts greenhouse-gas emissions, and can also sometimes cause less pollution when they degrade in the environment. Companies such as fashion companies such as Lululemon are using plants to make chemically identical nylon that can be easily switched in, but still cuts emissions by nearly half. The European Union is considering mandating bioprax, while the U.S. government and the European Union are also considering biopastic packaging rules under consideration.
description: Bioplastic production is growing at a record clip amid strong demand from fashion and food-packaging companies, in particular.

summary: Several U.S. retailers have reported that sales have ebbed due to higher prices for food and other essentials. Macy's and Dr Martens' shares dropped after the company slashed its annual sales and profit forecasts for the year, sending shares of the company down 4%. Other retailers such as Macy's, Dollar General, and Dollar Tree all saw their shares slump due to weaker discretionary spending.
description: Weak profit forecasts from department store chain Macy's to discounter Dollar General on Thursday underscored the fragile health of the U.S. consumer as persistent inflation curbs spending.

summary: WestRock is nearing a deal to merge with Europe's Smurfit Kappa, a global paper and packaging giant worth around $20 billion. The merger could be announced next week, if the talks don't fall apart. WestRock and SmURfit Kappa have not immediately responded to Reuters requests for a comment.
description: WestRock is nearing a deal to merge with Europe's Smurfit Kappa, a move that could create a global paper and packaging giant worth around $20 billion, the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday. The merger could be announced next week, if the talks don't fall apart, WSJ reported, citing people familiar with the matter. WestRock and Smurfit Kappa did not immediately respond to Reuters requests for a comment.

summary: Conservative columnist David French suggested that Fox News' reasons for lying to its viewers go deeper than money, power and fame. He suggested that the network's behavior was to blame for the recent controversy surrounding its on-air personalities, who were secretly texting and emailing each other. French also suggested that if conservative Christians face a threat to their civil liberties, the first call is to Fox if they want to sell a book, and Fox takes those calls. He also noted that Fox and its highly influential evening hosts have gone off the rails, and that there are courageous reporters at Fox who have courage to tell the truth.
description: Questions continue to be raised over Fox News executives allowing on-air personalities to continue to spout conspiracy rumors about the 2020 presidential election results while at the same time they were privately texting and emailing each other, acknowledging that they were helping to spread lies.W...

summary: Tyson Foods is experimenting with how robots can improve interactions with a variety of biological tissues. The company has relied more on automation to perform some of its operations, and is investing $1.3 billion in automation in the coming years. The technology can also fill in some positions where labor is tight and reduce injuries and worker fatigue. Since opening, more than 650 Tyson employees from across the nation have received training at TMAC. A recent survey of 2,000 workers found only about 14% had electronic competition. Tyson plans to spend about $2.5 billion in fiscal 2023 on "capacity expansion and ‚Äö√Ñ¬∂ automation to alleviate labor challenges" and product R&D.
description: Tyson Foods researchers are experimenting with how robots can improve interactions with a variety of biological tissues.

summary: Senators have introduced legislation to increase competition in live ticketing by preventing ticketing companies from locking up venues in long-term exclusive contracts. The Unlock Ticketing Markets Act, sponsored by Sens. Amy Klobuchar and Richard Blumenthal, would allow the Federal Trade Commission to prevent the use of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫excessively long‚Äö√Ñ√π multi-year exclusive contracts with event venues. The bill would have the FTC determine the period of time that constitutes ‚Äö√Ñ√≤excessive duration‚Äö√Ñ√π of such exclusive contracts, but says the minimum would be anything more than four years. Separately, Sens. Ted Cruz and Maria Cantwell also introduced a bill targeting what they call hidden ticket fees that often appear late in the check-out process. Live Nation Entertainment Inc., owner of Ticketmaster, the largest concert promoter and ticketing service, didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t immediately comment on the legislation. An AEG spokesman disputed that comment, saying they had a choice.
description: Senators have introduced a bill to curb long-term exclusive contracts between ticket sellers and venues.

summary: President Joe Biden praised ticketing websites Ticketmaster and SeatGeek Inc. for their initiatives aimed at making it easier for consumers to see all the costs upfront for sports, concerts, and theater performances. Tickets purchased on Ticketmaster for events at venues also owned by parent Live Nation Entertainment Inc. will default to display an all-in price that includes mandatory fees that currently aren‚Äö√Ñ√¥t shown until later in the checkout process. Ticketmaster‚Äö√Ñ√¥s upfront pricing changes only apply to venues it also owns, not stadium and concert halls. The White House said that Live Nation reached out to the administration after Biden called for an elimination of junk fees during his State of the Union address.
description: President Joe Biden lauded ticketing websites Ticketmaster and SeatGeek Inc. for initiatives aimed at making it easier for consumers to see all the costs upfront for sports, concerts, and theater performances and urged other companies to adopt similar practices.

summary: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has reported that several government agencies have been hit by a cyberattack, while Chinese spies appear to have separately infiltrated hundreds of public and private networks around the world. The U.N. cybersecurity firm Mandiant, owned by Google, believes that state-backed Chinese hackers conducted a massive cyberattack on hundreds of private and public networks. The victims of the Chinese cyberattack included organizations located in the Americas, Asia Pacific, Europe, Middle East, and Africa.
description: Several U.S. government agencies have reportedly been hit by a cyberattack while Chinese spies appear to have separately infiltrated hundreds of public and private networks around the world. summary:
Google Case Before High Court Could Reshape Internet Economy. 

The oversight of Google and other internet platforms is shifting to the courts from Congress.

summary:
In the wake of the Taylor Swift ticket sales disaster that left scores of fans empty-handed or price-gouged, the Senate Judiciary Committee began questioning a series of witnesses on Tuesday to determine whether Live Nation, Ticketmaster‚Äö√Ñ√¥s parent company, wields a monopoly over the concert-going industry and should be dismantled.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Let‚Äö√Ñ√¥s take the Taylor Swift fiasco as an example,‚Äö√Ñ√π Jerry Mickelson, an independent concert promoter and the co-founder of Jam Productions, said at the hearing when asked why it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s so difficult for the average consumer to buy concert tickets.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫The fans had to sign up through a Verified Fan [service] to even buy a ticket,‚Äö√Ñ√π Mickelson said. I think that it was driven by Ticketmaster‚Äö√Ñ√¥s bottom line in the Taylor Swift fiasco.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Antitrust complaints against Ticketmaster have been going on long before the company cancelled its main sale for Swift tickets last year, resulting in hundreds of thousands of snubbed fans‚Äö√Ñ√ÆPearl Jam leveled a complaint against the company in 2004. Joe Berchtold, president and CFO of Live Nation Entertainment, began his address to members of the committee by stating that his company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s system is ‚Äö√Ñ√∫best in class,‚Äö√Ñ√π but went on to claim that the problems encountered by Swift fans when they were attempting to buy tickets were largely due to bot attacks.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫In hindsight there are several things we could have done better,‚Äö√Ñ√π Berchtold said. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫And let me be clear, Ticketmaster accepts its responsibility as being the first line in defense against bots in our industry.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Sen. Marsha Blackburn expressed frustration that Live Nation evidently wasn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t handling bots with more skill. Other issues that were brought up during the hearing had to do with purchasing event tickets, such as massive hidden fees of up to 82 percent on top of ticket prices, as well as speculative ticket sales, in which resellers sell tickets that they technically don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have yet to secondary buyers at hugely inflated sums.

Connecticut Sen. Richard Blumenthal later scoffed at what he deemed to be Ticketmaster‚Äö√Ñ√¥s attempts to place the blame for the Eras Tour debacle on Swift herself, who was not present at the hearing.
description: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Ticketmaster ought to look in the mirror and say, ‚Äö√Ñ√≤I‚Äö√Ñ√¥m the problem, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s me,‚Äö√Ñ√¥‚Äö√Ñ√π one senator said during the hearing examining the company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s dominance in the concert industry.

A warehouse crush across the U.S. is squeezing out smaller companies as big retailers fill industrial storage sites with their growing stockpiles of inventory.

Logistics and real-estate specialists say many large retailers are demanding extra room to store excess inventories, driving up costs for smaller companies and in some cases driving them out of spaces.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s tough for the small guy,‚Äö√Ñ√π Ms. Galena said, noting labor and other costs are rising for warehouse operators.

The challenges small businesses face finding warehouse space mirrors difficulties many had securing room on container ships earlier in the Covid-19 pandemic, when ocean carriers drove up rates and bumped smaller shippers to make way for larger clients.

description: The maker of Oral B toothbrushes and Bounty paper towels said sales in its second quarter ended in December fell 1% from a year earlier.  On an organic basis, stripping out currency fluctuations, sales were up 5%.  On a conference call, Chief Executive  Jon Moeller  repeatedly struck a gloomy tone on the state of global affairs.

summary:
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The larger companies have a lot of experience, they have the legal expertise and just a long history of dealing with regulators, so they‚Äö√Ñ√¥re ... well positioned‚Äö√Ñ√π to succeed in e-cigarettes, CFRA Research analyst Garrett Nelson tells Axios. 

Keep in mind: Like smoking, vaping is addictive because e-cigarettes contain nicotine, the same addictive ingredient that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s in cigarettes.
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ The Biden administration‚Äö√Ñ√¥s FDA has been cracking down on the industry. Goldman Sachs analyst Bonnie Herzog wrote Friday that the move to terminate the non-compete is "very positive" for Altria, noting that the company can now pursue revenue from vaping while also retaining its stake in Juul, thus potentially capitalizing on any potential upside if Juul takes a turn for the better. 

The other side: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫This decision gives us more flexibility as it increases the financial and strategic options we can pursue to secure our business and address the impact of the FDA‚Äö√Ñ√¥s now stayed order,‚Äö√Ñ√π Juul said in a statement, adding that the company is ‚Äö√Ñ√∫confident‚Äö√Ñ√π in its ability to meet the FDA‚Äö√Ñ√¥s requirements to get back onto the market.
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ Nelson, however, said he‚Äö√Ñ√¥s skeptical that Juul will reemerge as a competitor in the U.S.: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Most analysts are looking at it as a fairly low probability because this administration is cracking down on tobacco more than the prior administration.‚Äö√Ñ√π

What‚Äö√Ñ√¥s next: If Altria decides to go the acquisition route, expect the company to target vaping businesses that have already obtained preliminary FDA approval to sell and market their products under the new regulatory regime that Juul has failed to navigate, Nelson says.
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ "They know the players in the industry, they‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve done their homework, so if they‚Äö√Ñ√¥re gonna make a move, it could happen fairly quickly,‚Äö√Ñ√π Nelson says.
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ ‚Äö√Ñ√∫But they have to have assurance they‚Äö√Ñ√¥re not going to be making a similar mistake as Juul, so I think they‚Äö√Ñ√¥ll be more careful in their due diligence process.
description: Big Tobacco giant Altria takes on Juul: Non-compete deal is off

summary: Australia's Newcrest Mining Ltd, which has received a $26.2 billion takeover offer from Newmont Corp, posted a nearly 11% fall in annual profit on Friday due to lower realised prices for copper and a rise in operating and finance costs. The country's largest listed gold miner said its underlying profit was $778 million for the year ended June 30, compared with $872 million a year earlier and analysts' estimates of $689.7 million. The company expects its 2024 gold production to be in the range of 2.0 million to 2.3 million ounces. Shares of the Melbourne-headquartered miner were down 0.4% after rising nearly 0.2% in early trade. The meeting with Newmont will be held in October, with implementation targeted for November 2023. The all-in sustaining cost, a key industry metric that reflects total expenses associated with production, was $1,093 per ounce for the 2023 fiscal year.
description: Australia's Newcrest Mining Ltd , which has received a A$26.2 billion takeover offer from Newmont Corp, posted a near 11% fall in annual profit on Friday, hurt by lower realised prices for copper and a rise in operating and finance costs.  The country's largest listed gold miner said its underlying profit was $778 million for the year ended June 30, compared with $872 million a year earlier and analysts' estimates of $689.7 million, according to Refinitiv data.  Newcrest expects its 2024 gold production to be in the range of 2.0 million to 2.3 million ounces.

summary:
Why it matters: This comes shortly after Kroger agreed to buy Albertsons for $24.6 billion, putting pressure on others in the industry to consolidate. Background: The Jacksonville, Fla.-based retailer canceled IPO plans last year. 

The bottom line: Southeastern Grocers could become a consolation prize for either Kroger or Albertsons, were their merger to be blocked by antitrust regulators. But, as Axios Pro's Richard Collings notes, it also may be removing itself as a bidder for the hundreds of stores that Kroger would need to divest were its Albertsons deal to go through.
description: Move comes as antitrust regulators dig into Kroger's megamerger with Albertsons.

summary: The Council Post has published a report on the difference between shopper-targeted media and shopper marketing, discussing the importance of understanding the differences between these two forms of marketing. The report explains how the rapid evolution of advertising has created a gray area between marketing subdivisions that were once more siloed. It also explains how shoppers are being targeted using behavioral and demographic targeting to target consumers online, while shopper Marketing is being used to target high-intent shoppers and drive sales. The Council Post also discusses the overlap between teams and budgets, as well as the fact that many advertisers are hoping to achieve a similar outcome with shopper targeting media as they are with shoppers.
description: By strategically implementing both strategies, your brand can go further and drive commerce growth.

summary: Jose De Hoyos, founder of the cryptocurrency consulting firm LFG Mining, is recruiting engineers in the oil patch to join drilling crews. The push comes at a precarious moment for the gas industry, as developers are racing to build massive projects in Texas to liquefy and export US gas to make up for reduced Russian pipeline flows to Europe in the wake of the Ukraine invasion. Companies are facing a shortage of workers due to rising expenses and higher interest rates, and competition from tech companies has made it difficult to fill roles for LNG-specific roles. Across the US, US companies are struggling to find low-paying workers amid low-employment opportunities.
description: Jose De Hoyos is recruiting in the oil patch. He got his start meeting workers in Pennsylvania‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Marcellus shale basin. This month, you‚Äö√Ñ√¥ll find him glad-handing in Odessa, Texas.

summary: Emerson Electric Secures Key Role In $6B Chemical Project In Middle East. ‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ None Emerson Electric Co (NYSE: EMR) will provide automation technologies, software and analytics for the Ras Laffan Petrochemical Complex in Qatar. ‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ None Emerson will be a part of a consortium with Viasat Energy Services, a division of global communications company Viasat Inc (NASDAQ: VSAT). "Our advanced automation and analytics solutions will play a key role in the safe and efficient operation of this world-class facility," said Vidya Ramnath, president of Emerson's Middle East & Africa business.

Emerson will be a part of a consortium with Viasat Energy Services, a division of global communications company Viasat Inc (NASDAQ: VSAT). The $6 billion integrated polymers project is currently under construction and scheduled to go online in late 2026. The complex will include an ethane cracker with a capacity of 2.1 million tonnes of ethylene per year

summary: The Michigan Public Service Commission has launched an investigation into Jackson-based Consumers Energy after receiving complaints from customers about malfunctioning natural gas meters, potential overbilling due to extended estimated meter readings and delays in new service installations. The need for an investigation was determined after MPSC received complaints about customers who were frustrated by malfunctioning meters not showing the amount of electricity used. The complaints came as the utility worked to transition its electric meters from using 3G cellular telephone technology to 4G-based meters, and the meters were not working and showed blank screens, meaning both customers and Consumers Energy could not pull actual readings from the meters. The order directs the utility to provide information to the commission such as an explanation of its communications with customers about estimated reads and whether customers were receiving estimated readings due to the 3G issue or because of malfunctioning meter readings by Aug. 4. Separately, Consumers Energy is proposing a targeted undergrounding pilot program pending approval from the PSC.
description: MPSC said it has received complaints from customers about malfunctioning meters, potential overbilling and delays in new service installations.

summary: Lennar Corp., the second-largest US homebuilder, is calling an end to falling housing prices, but doesn't yet see a recovery in sight. Executive Chairman Stuart Miller said Thursday that the outlook for the future is subject to change in the event of interest rates moving higher. Lennar is heading for its highest close on record, eclipsing the $116.91 mark set in December 2021. The company's shares rose 3.7% to $119 at 2:23 p.m. in New York, buoyed by Lennar‚Äö√Ñ√¥s boost in its forecast for full-year new-home deliveries and quarterly beats against estimates for gross margins and new orders. However, lower prices have dented Lennar's profitability, a metric Miller said is likely to remain lower than it once was.

summary: China Recovery, Cooling Inventories and Store Strength Likely to Define Earnings Results. After years of store closures and temporary shutdowns, many retailers are going all in on strategic store expansion plans. Neiman Marcus has also made a $200 million strategic investment in stores over three years to add space for style advisors as well as food and beverage concepts to make it a top destination for luxury consumers. Other retailers with store opening plans for 2023 include Academy Sports + Outdoors, Boot Barn, Dollar General, Ralph Lauren, REI and more.

summary: Union Pacific Corp. reported lower operating income as softening volumes from customers, higher costs from weather interruptions in California and inflation kept profits muted in the most recent quarter. The railroad said operating income declined 3% in the first quarter while business volumes fell 1% as fewer carloads of industrial chemicals, forest products and grain offset higher demand from the automotive industry. Freight revenue rose 4% to $5.7 billion.
description: Fewer carloads of industrial chemicals, forest products and grain offset higher demand from the automotive industry, the railroad said.

summary: Senator Sherrod Brown, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs, has sent letters to the CEOs of the country's biggest banks asking them what they plan to do about the looming threat of fake voices created with artificial intelligence being used to break into customers‚Äö√Ñ√¥ accounts. The move comes after Motherboard used an AI-powered system to clone a reporter‚Äö√Ñ√¥s voice, and then used that to fool a bank's voice authentication security system. Brown's letter to the banks asks each to describe their use of voice authentication services, including whether they are using third-party provided tools; how frequently customers use voice authentication; and where customer voice data is stored.
description: The move comes after Motherboard used AI voice cloning technology to fool a bank‚Äö√Ñ√¥s security systems.

summary: A Tale of Two Consumers: JPMorgan Chase vs. Discover Financial's Credit Card Trends. Both JPMorgan Chase (NYSE: JPM) and Discover Financial Services (NYSE: DFS) are large credit card lenders that recently reported their fourth-quarter earnings results and provided early guidance for full-year 2023. JPMorgan Chase reported that it expects its credit card net charge-off (NCO) rate to jump from 1.47% at the end of 2022 to about 2.6% by the end of 2023. The NCO looks at credit card debt unlikely to be collected as a percentage of the total credit card loan portfolio.

summary: Two new Apple bugs have been identified, allowing hackers to access images and messages on iOS 16.3. These vulnerabilities allow them to access calendars, addresses, photos and videos and stored files. Security experts have advised users to use trusted apps in the App Store and not open messages from unknown senders. It is unclear how long the vulnerabilities have been plaguing devices, but Apple has released a software update with multiple bug fixes and Crash Detection optimizations.
description: Privacy experts are sounding the alarm on two newly discovered vulnerabilities plaguing iPhones - less than 10 days since Apple revealed others that let attackers take over devices.

summary:
FILE PHOTO: Bottles of Coca-Cola are seen at a Carrefour Hypermarket store in Montreuil, near Paris

(Reuters) -Coca-Cola HBC AG raised its full-year profit forecast on Tuesday, as the soft drinks bottler benefited from resilient demand and said price rises and promotions would protect profits. 

Inflation at multi-year highs has pinched household budgets and forced consumers to cut their spending, but Coca-Cola is among the packaged food makers enjoying steady demand. 

Chief Executive Zoran Bogdanovic said trading in the fourth quarter and 2023 "might get harder because of consumer demand suppression," but added the company planned to overcome it with pricing and promotional plans. 

Shares in the company rose 4% to 2,007 pence in early trading.

summary: Bunge is buying Viterra in a deal valued at approximately $18 billion to create an agricultural powerhouse. The deal will involve 65.6 million shares of Bunge stock, valued at $6.2 billion and about $2 billion in cash. Bunge will assume $9.8 billion of Vitterra debt and its grain and softseed handling capacity will grow while it expands origination capabilities in key regions and crops where Bunge doesn't have a strong presence. The board of the combined company will include eight Bunge directors and four representatives nominated by ViterRA shareholders after the deal closes. The transaction is targeted to close by the middle of next year, but still needs approval from Bunge Inc. shareholders.

3M (MMM) to Cease Manufacture of Harmful PFAS by 2025-End. 



The move comes amid regulatory pressure to restrict the use of PFAS and customers increasingly looking for alternatives to the harmful substance. MMM said that the use of PFAS in products has weighed on its results over the past few years. 



3M has already minimized the usage of PFAS over the past three years and aims to continue developing solutions for customers to replace this harmful chemical.

summary: The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) has announced that it will be providing low-interest loans to small businesses impacted by the recent I-95 collapse as part of its Economic Injury Disaster Loan Program. The SBA only offers these loans directly to businesses and homeowners recovering from a declared disaster. Other financing options the agency offers include Section 7(a) loans, 504 Loan Program, and $50,000 in microloans to eligible small businesses through designated intermediary lenders. All of these loans are guaranteed by the US government, with rates and fees that are comparable to non-aranteed loans. However, small business owners applying should be prepared to make the money available.
description: SBA offers Economic Injury Disaster Loans directly to businesses and homeowners recovering from a declared disaster, but there are options for other businesses who might need extra financial help.

summary:
Here‚Äö√Ñ√¥s a suggestion: start with small business. 

Prioritizing small businesses will loosen political gridlock because they offer both parties a way to support job creation, reinvigorate struggling communities, and enhance U.S. competitiveness. In our conversations with scores of small businesses over the past two years, we have heard repeated iterations of this observation: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫tax credits are too expensive for small businesses to take advantage of.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Hiring challenges hurt job creation and business growth: nine in 10 respondents in the Voices survey say difficulty hiring affects their bottom line. Congress could help by directing the Small Business Administration (SBA) and other agencies to increase awareness of what‚Äö√Ñ√¥s already available for small businesses, reforming existing tax credits for small employers, and creating options that work better for small businesses.
description: In a closely divided Congress, lawmakers can find no better starting point for bipartisan work together than support for small business.

summary: Watchdog has called out SBA for not paying more overtime wages for collections for PPP loans, and has called for businesses to prepare for increased overtime wages due to the SVB failure. Pacific Business News reports that businesses are now looking to find a solution for their payrolls after SVB failed to provide services for new hires.

summary: The exchange-traded fund industry is moving quickly with new products to address the banking crisis. Roundhill Investments launched its new Big Bank ETF (BIGB) on Tuesday in response to the crisis, which includes no regional banks but holds equally weighted positions in six institutions. The launch of the ETF comes as larger banks are increasingly being seen as relative safe havens in the sector, while regional bank stocks remain volatile this week. Financial ETFs have garnered 51% of the sector traffic on VettaFi sites in the past week, compared with 12% the week prior and 5% at the start of the year. The Fed has launched its own internal review about the oversight of SVB and Signature, which it says will be released by May 1.
description: As regional banks continue to recover from the Silicon Valley Bank collapse, the ETF industry is rolling out a new product to address the turbulence.
