summary: The State Corporation Commission has approved Dominion Energy Virginia's development plans for a set of new solar and energy storage resources. The projects, which will be owned and operated by Dominion, will generate more than 800 megawatts, enough to power about 200,000 homes at peak output. They are expected to add 38 cents to the average residential customer‚Äö√Ñ√¥s monthly bill and result in $250 million in fuel savings over their first 10 years.
description: RICHMOND, Va. (AP) ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ State regulators on Friday approved Dominion Energy Virginia's development plans for a set of new solar and energy storage resources. In a written order , the State Corporation Commission signed off on nine solar projects and an energy storage project that will be owned and operated by Dominion, the company said in a news release.

summary: Marathon Petroleum Corp reported a 63% drop in second-quarter profit on Tuesday, as improved fuel supplies and slowing economic activity compressed its margins. Despite an increase in global refining capacity over the last year and slowing activity, the market has declined significantly since Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Refining capacity utilization fell to 93% from 100% a year earlier, with planned maintenance in the Mid-Continent and West Coast regions resulting in total throughput of 2.9 million barrels per day (bpd) for the quarter ended June 30. The refiner projected crude throughput of 3.7 million bpd for the third quarter due to lower turnaround activity. On an adjusted basis, earnings of $5.32 per share beat analysts' average estimate of $4.59, on the back of lower refining costs and tax rates.
description: U.S. refiner Marathon Petroleum Corp reported a 63% drop in second-quarter profit on Tuesday, as improved fuel supplies and slowing economic activity compressed its margins.  Despite resilient fuel demand in the U.S., an increase in global refining capacity over the last year and slowing economic activity has brought the market down from the peaks in 2022.  Distillate fuel prices, which soared after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, have fallen on easing uncertainty over how subsequent sanctions would affect the market, said Brian Partee, senior vice president at Marathon.

summary: Employers are looking to fill more office seats in 2023 due to the push and pull over working conditions in a post-COVID business environment. Companies must carefully implement, and measure, a return to office life. This will most likely be an issue at large companies, which invest a lot in physical locations, and small companies may be more flexible. Companies need to consider what employees value with remote work and incorporate those things in the office. Companies also need to think about the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫why‚Äö√Ñ√π behind their decisions, how to message changes and how to manage them.
description: Employers are looking to fill more office seats in 2023. It reflects the push and pull over working conditions in a post-COVID business environment.

summary:
CBRE defers "around half" of Q3 UK property fund withdrawals - spokesperson. 

LONDON, Jan 5 (Reuters) - CBRE Investment Management has deferred by three months the payment of some third-quarter redemption requests in its UK Property Authorised Investment Fund, a spokesperson for the firm said on Thursday, due to "ongoing market conditions." 

Investors who put in requests to withdraw money from the fund will receive "around half" of their redemption payments in January, with the remainder to follow "as soon as practically possible", the spokesperson said by email.
description: CBRE Investment Management has deferred by three months the payment of some third-quarter redemption requests in its UK Property Authorised Investment Fund, a spokesperson for the firm said on Thursday, due to "ongoing market conditions."

summary:
Two people died overnight in upstate New York and hundreds were stuck for hours on an interstate in Kentucky on Saturday morning before an evacuation. 

At a press conference on Saturday, New York Gov. Kathy Hochul said 73,000 homes in the region were without power, adding that she planned to ask the federal government for a declaration of emergency. 

Meanwhile, on Saturday morning more than 700 vehicles were stranded for hours in Kentucky on a 14-mile stretch of interstate as emergency responders struggled to clear the roadway, Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear said. 

Meredith and Matthew Mikesell ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ a married couple from Louisville, Kentucky ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ previously told a local ABC News affiliate on Saturday morning that they had been stuck on the interstate for nearly 12 hours.
description: As the holiday travel rush begins, a cross-country storm is bringing heavy snow, blizzard conditions and damaging winds.

summary:
Thousands of flights grounded as winter storm death toll rises to 18. 

Thousands of flights have been cancelled and delayed in the wake of Winter Storm Elliott, according to flight tracking data. 

Temperatures dropped to as low as -40C in some places, and nearly 60 per cent of the US population was subject to some form of winter advisory. The National Weather Service said the storm has prompted "one of the greatest extents of winter weather warnings and advisories ever."
description: Temperatures fell to as low as -40C in some areas

summary:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday rebuffed a bid by Bristol Myers Squibb Co's Juno Therapeutics Inc to reinstate a $1.2 billion award it won in its patent fight with Gilead Sciences Inc subsidiary Kite Pharma Inc over a lymphoma drug. Juno and Sloan Kettering have told the Supreme Court that the Federal Circuit's decision to invalidate the patent and other rulings against biologic patents have been "devastating for innovation." 

Biologic drugs are made from biological cells, unlike traditional pharmaceuticals. 

Kite said in a brief to the Supreme Court that the Federal Circuit's decision was in line with longstanding patent law and that Juno's patent had "tried to monopolize - and block everyone else from investigating - millions of billions of possible drug candidates at the infancy of a field."

On Nov. 4, the Supreme Court took up another patent case involving biologic drugs, agreeing to hear Amgen's bid to revive patents on its cholesterol drug Repatha.
description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday rebuffed a bid by Bristol Myers Squibb Co's Juno Therapeutics Inc to reinstate a $1.2 billion award it won in its patent fight with Gilead Sciences Inc subsidiary Kite Pharma Inc over a lymphoma drug.  The justices turned away Juno's appeal of a lower court's ruling throwing out the award in the litigation over Kite's biologic drug Yescarta, in a case that could have repercussions for the cutting-edge biologic drug industry.  Juno and Sloan Kettering Institute for Cancer Research sued Kite in 2017 in federal court in Los Angeles, accusing it of copying technology that the institute licenses to Juno.

summary: Centene reported first quarter profits of more than $1.1 billion as membership grew by more than 2 million thanks to an increase in Obamacare and Medicaid enrollment. Total managed care membership increased by over 2 million members to 28.45 million, compared to 26.2 million at the end of the first quarter of 2022. Centene‚Äö√Ñ√¥s revenues jumped 3% to $38.88 billion from $37.18 billion in the year-ago quarter, while net income was $1 billion. The company increased its 2023 full year adjusted earnings per share guidance to ‚Äö√Ñ√∫at least $6.40 driven by strong performance in its market leading Medicaid and Marketplace businesses. The Biden administration said earlier this year that an all-time record of over 16 million Americans have signed up for 2023 healthcare coverage.
description: Centene reported more than $1.1 billion in first quarter profits thanks to a big boost in Obamacare enrollment.

summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency has sent letters to AT&T, Verizon (VZ) and Verizon (T.N) seeking information in its ongoing review of risks posed by lead-clad telecom cables. The EPA is closely reviewing the issues raised in the Wall Street Journal‚Äö√Ñ√¥s recent investigation of telecom cables that contain lead. Over the coming weeks, EPA will conduct independent sampling starting in Coal Center, Pennsylvania and West Orange, New Jersey.
description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday it sent letters to AT&T and Verizon requiring both companies to quickly provide the agency with information in its ongoing review of risks posed by lead-clad telecom cables.

summary: Barclays Plc has earmarked cash from its balance sheet to hold corporate loans and compete directly with private credit funds. The strategy involves purchasing slugs of debt originated by the bank and participating in new financings arranged by direct lending funds. This move comes as the private credit market has morphed into a go-to avenue to finance multi-billion dollar buyouts. Banks have started to repopulate their deal pipelines in recent months, landing roles on large financingings as credit conditions in the public markets improved. Other banks have also sought to snare a piece of the action in private credit, with JPMorgan Chase & Co. holding aside $10 billion to refocus its approach to direct lending.
description: Barclays Plc has earmarked cash from its balance sheet to hold corporate loans and compete directly with private credit funds, according to people with knowledge of the matter, as more banks look for ways to gain a foothold in the $1.5 trillion market for private debt.

summary:
Even with the deceleration, prices remain high compared to last year. Coupled with mortgage rates that are edging closer to 7%, many would-be buyers have been shut out, while some sellers have retreated.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫The forceful deceleration in US housing prices that we noted a month ago continued,‚Äö√Ñ√π Craig Lazzara, a managing director at S&P Dow Jones Indices, said in the statement. Sales of existing homes fell for an eighth straight month in September, according to National Association of Realtors data, while new home construction also dropped in September, according to recent government data. 

‚Äö√Ñ√∫As we move into the colder months of the year, we can expect further declines in home sales and continued downward adjustment in prices,‚Äö√Ñ√π said George Ratiu, manager of economic research at Realtor.com.
description: The U.S. housing market has started to slump as the Federal Reserve hikes interest rates. Prices are still up over 2021, but were lower in August than in July.

summary: UPS and the Teamsters union have reached a massive five-year labor deal that includes big wage increases and other improvements to work rules and schedules. The parties had until July 31, when the previous labor contract was set to expire, to reach a deal and avoid a work stoppage. Part-time workers will make no less than $21 an hour, up from a minimum of $15.50 currently, according to the union. The agreement is the single largest collective bargaining agreement ever reached in the private sector. It follows the recent success of American Airlines pilots who have also ratified a four-year deal with their pilots' union.
description: The agreement is the largest collective bargaining agreement at a private-sector employer based on number of workers.

summary: Indonesia will stop exporting copper concentrates as soon as Freeport Indonesia and Amman Mineral Internasional finish building smelters next year. President Joko Widodo expects both facilities to start producing in May 2024. The government has had to push back its plans for an export ban several times as the local unit of Freeport McMoRan Inc., the world‚Äö√Ñ√¥s top copper producer, kept seeking extensions for a smelter that was started in 2021. Last week, Indonesia granted both Freeport and amman export recommendations to continue shipping copper concentrate until their smeltering is finished.
description: Indonesia will stop exporting copper concentrates as soon as Freeport Indonesia and Amman Mineral Internasional finish building smelters next year.

summary: A security expert has revealed his top five tips for making smartphones harder to hack. These tips include keeping your device's operating system (OS) and apps updated, avoiding public Wi-Fi networks, and using antivirus and security apps to detect and prevent malware and other threats. Finally, he recommends using strong, unique passwords for all accounts and enabling multi-factor authentication (MFA) to protect against any potential attacks.
description: A CYBERSECURITY expert has revealed his top five tips that anyone can do to make their smartphones far harder to hack. Sedric Louissaint has spent almost a decade in the industry and has hacked eve‚Äö√Ñ¬∂

summary:
Credit card debt is harder for younger consumers to handle amid the pressures of living paycheck to paycheck. Where 5% of millennials and 4.5% of Gen Z consumers have credit card debt that is more than 60 days delinquent, just 3.5% of Gen X borrowers and 1.8% of boomers are behind on payments like that. 

Inflation and the higher cost of living are taking a toll on middle-class household finances, with many people turning to credit cards to make up for income shortfalls. 

What To Do with Gift Cards You Don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t Want

Most of us have that one family member or friend whose go-to gift each Christmas is a gift card.
description: What took place this week in the credit card and payment industries

summary: UBS analyst Joshua Spector upgraded shares of Sealed Air Corp to $59 per share, suggesting a 28.8% rally from Tuesday's close price. He believes that demand volumes for vacuum sealed plastics packaging for fresh meat should become positive in the third quarter of this year, and that increased use of plastic packaging on fresh meats could extend shelf life. Shares have tumbled 30% during the past 12 months due to supply chain issues, a post-pandemic demand reset and industrial destocking. Roughly three-fifths of analysts covering SealedAir rate it a hold, Refinitiv data shows. The average price target on shares implies 24.5% upside over the next 12 months.
description: Analyst Joshua Spector upgraded shares to buy from neutral. He maintained his price target of $59 per share.

summary: A longtime Republican Representative from the Dallas-Fort Worth area has filed legislation calling for a constitutional amendment election to legalize casino and sports gambling in Texas, including at Lone Star Park horse race track in Grand Prairie. Political and sports industry leaders in Dallas and Fort Worth have been pushing for expanded gambling to allow casinos for the jobs, tourism and economic benefits it would bring to North Texas. The Las Vegas Sands corporation and others in the gambling industry have hired an army of lobbyists and are spending millions to push their case in Austin. The lobbying push is also underway in this session, with House Joint Resolution 97 allowing for up to seven casino destination resorts across the state. It is too early to tell how feasible it is to get any type of gambling expansion in Texas this session.
description: North House Republican files constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling in Texas

summary:
Necessity being the mother of invention, some Palm Beach County employers are thinking of innovative ways to attract and retain workers. 

Staffing is an issue Palm Beach County companies have been grappling with for the past year, and it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s not just confined to tourism and hospitality. 

Amidon agreed that an allowance might be needed in the future to offset housing costs and attract or retain workers. 

Gary Lesser, president of The Florida Bar and managing partner of the Lesser, Lesser, Landy & Smith in West Palm Beach, said his firm not only gave employees raises, it also switched to a permanent hybrid work arrangement to allow employees to work from home some days, and save on transportation costs.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫We don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have any plans on changing back,‚Äö√Ñ√π Lesser said.
description: Employers finding new ways to find, retain workers

summary:
Credit-reporting firms face more U.S. scrutiny as complaints jump.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said it found deficiencies in how credit-reporting companies including TransUnion, Equifax and Experian handle complaints about consumer data, as the agency explores new rules to rein in the industry.

Those three companies ‚Äö√Ñ√∫routinely top the list of complaints submitted by consumers,‚Äö√Ñ√π CFPB Director Rohit Chopra said in a statement Tuesday announcing the agency‚Äö√Ñ√¥s annual report on credit and consumer-reporting complaints. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Policymakers and market participants can shape the future of collecting, using and sharing consumers‚Äö√Ñ√¥ data in a manner that navigates successfully from surveillance to participation.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Consumer complaints are one indicator of whether markets are serving consumers, and ‚Äö√Ñ√∫complaints about credit reporting suggest that the system increasingly is not,‚Äö√Ñ√π the agency said. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The number of CFPB complaints has increased over the past several years.‚Äö√Ñ√π

The agency also offered recommendations for how the companies could improve their interactions with consumers, including by taking into account how automated processes might be an added burden. The industry should also acknowledge that flaws in consumer data could stem from the lack of individual autonomy over the information.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Enabling increased consumer participation on the data side of consumer reporting has the potential to create a fairer market with added benefits for consumers, consumer-reporting companies and lenders,‚Äö√Ñ√π the agency said in the statement.
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said it fielded approximately 488,000 complaints about credit-reporting companies from October 2021 to September 2022.

summary: The New York Stock Exchange has seen a sharp selloff in regional banks, following the March failure of Silicon Valley Bank and the recent takeover of First Republic by JPMorgan Chase. Wall Street analysts and investors were looking forward to some calm, but the regional bank stocks he covers for KBW began plunging shortly after the start of regular trading. The steep declines were attributed to fears about uninsured deposits, worries about commercial real estate and coming regulation. Peter Orszag, CEO of financial advisory at Lazard, represented First Republic in its rescue efforts, said people are searching for answers and no one has a good one.
description: The sharp selloff in regional banks sparked by the March failure of Silicon Valley Bank resumed Tuesday, catching Wall Street analysts and investors off guard.

summary: JPMONON: The firm's outlook for the second year in a row is positive, as the business owners of the multibillion dollar industry are changing and the decisions they make have huge consequences for communities, cities, even entire countries. JPMorgan Deposits is predicting that this year's economic growth will be driven by the strong performance of the business.
description: JPMorgan Chase & Co.‚Äôs first-quarter deposits unexpectedly rose from the end of last year and the firm boosted its guidance for this year‚Äôs net interest income. Shares of the company surged in early trading in New York.

summary: This article takes a look at the recent events at the IMF-World Bank meetings in Washington, as well as the tensions between the U.S. and China. It also looks at the growing dislocations of trade and cooperation, with French President Emmanuel Macron calling on Europe to resist becoming ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs followers‚Äù as it challenges Beijing. The IMF put a tangible cost on it, estimating that the world could lose trillions of dollars of future economic output if it split into competing geopolitical blocs. Finance ministers and other global economic officials attempted to tamp down the fires of protectionism and fragmentation, while European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis and Fed Governor Christopher Waller discussed the economy in San Antonio at 8:45 a.m. and threatened to subpoena Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen with a subpoena if she didn't turn over documents related to FT founder Huizenga.
description: One big theme has hung over this week‚Äôs IMF-World Bank meetings: The global economy is coming apart at the seams and needs to be sewn back up.

summary: The retail giant announced on Wednesday that it is shedding workers in an attempt to control costs, with job cuts reportedly slated for its retail, devices and human-resources divisions. The job cuts are part of a wider trend, with Facebook‚Äö√Ñ√¥s parent company Meta last week announcing plans to reduce staff by 13 percent, equal to roughly 11,000 jobs, while Elon Musk confirmed the week prior he would cut Twitter‚Äö√Ñ√¥s staff numbers in half. Microsoft similarly announced ‚Äö√Ñ√∫structural adjustments‚Äö√Ñ√π, cutting around 1,000 jobs last month. According to Trachet‚Äö√Ñ√¥s research, 20 percent of British workers felt their firm was too slow to react and adapt to the approaching recession, which is what resulted in a loss of staff.
description: A new study revealed exclusively by Express.co.uk reveals a third of Britons are seeing fewer people at work as job cuts ravage the tech industry.

summary: According to new data from the federal government, energy prices dropped nearly 6 percent in the Boston metropolitan area between April 2022 and April 2023 due to falling gasoline prices. The per-therm price of natural gas rose 41 percent during that same period, and per-kilowatt hour electricity prices rose 107 percent. This was due to rate increases brought by the state's biggest utility providers, Eversource and National Grid, which increased their electricity delivery rate from last winter's 14.82 cents per kilowatt-hour rate to 33.89 cents this winter. The state Department of Public Utilities later ordered a 10 percent cut in natural gas rates in March after fear of a supply crunch didn't fully materialize. For summer, National Grid lowered electric rates from 33. 89 cents per kWh to 14.12 cents per kilometers.
description: If this winter felt much more expensive, it was. Electricity rates rose a whopping 107 percent, with natural gas rates close behind.

summary: FDA Seeks More Data on Lilly‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Alzheimer‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Drug Candidate. Lilly said it will work with the FDA to evaluate the fastest pathway to get its Alzheimer‚Äö√Ñ√¥s drug, donanemab, to market. U.S. drug regulators rejected Eli Lilly & Co.‚Äö√Ñ√¥s proposed new Alzheimer‚Äö√Ñ√¥s disease treatment, saying they need more data from clinical testing, according to the company. The setback could delay a potential commercial introduction of the highly anticipated drug by at least several months, if the Food and Drug Administration eventually decides to approve it.
description: The agency declined to grant approval, saying it wanted more data from study volunteers who had been on the highly anticipated new medicine.

summary: Curtin Blair, the president and CEO of the Utah Valley Chamber of Commerce, is sharing 10 articles on the importance of careful planning and preparation before taking action. He believes that organizations can maximize their chances of success by diligently gathering data, analyzing feedback, and making informed decisions during each iteration of their journey. This principle may ring familiar, as it was brought to life by Eric Ries' book: "The Lean Startup." Jim Evans, former vice president of Xactware and current executive director of America's Freedom Festival in Provo, emphasizes the significance of measuring and planning for success while introducing the idea of accountability. Evans also shares ideas that align directly with the principle of measuring twice and cutting once, such as hiring good people, and ensuring that employees understand their roles and the desired direction.
description: The axiom

summary: Businesses are facing an influx of new artificial-intelligence tools, many of which overlap and cause confusion for employees. Generative AI features, which can respond to user prompts by generating images or text, often come in the forms of co-pilots or virtual assistants that work in tandem with an IT seller‚Äö√Ñ√¥s offerings. This has caused confusion among employees looking for a single common interface to accomplish certain tasks, and security concerns. Tech executives are looking critically at new generative AI tools to distinguish between the compelling ones and the ones that are just paying lip service to the hype.
description: IT sellers are rolling out an avalanche of new generative AI features, leaving CIOs overwhelmed and workers confused.

summary: Fox News was awarded $787.5 million in a lawsuit by Dominion Voting Systems, a hitherto obscure election machinery company. The case was part of a larger effort to expose the abuse of media power by Rupert Murdoch's Fox News, and Fox News has had to ‚Äö√Ñ√∫acknowledge‚Äö√Ñ√π its failures and the most basic deceptions a ‚Äö√Ñ√∫news‚Äö√Ñ√π organisation can perpetrate on its audience. Dominion also faces a $2.7 billion defamation lawsuit filed by another voting technology company, Smartmatic, that alleges Fox broadcast lies that ‚Äö√Ñ√∫decimated‚Äö√Ñ√π their business. This case shows that the lies are having consequences because they cost two corporations a great deal of money, and they are pursuing their right to restitution.
description: The victory is hardly going to transform our devalued political culture

summary: Medtronic is facing sluggish sales growth, is in midst of deep cost-cutting and has started ongoing global layoffs. Wall Street analysts have predicted a consensus revenue estimate of $8.25 billion for the quarter, a 2% increase over the year-ago period. The company has resisted providing specifics in other areas such as job cuts and the expansion of the Medtronic Engineering & Innovation Center (MEIC) in Hyderabad, India. Despite this, analysts remain skeptical that this is the final piece of the puzzle for the diabetes business.
description: The company is investing more than $350 million, adding jobs in India during global belt-tightening.

summary: The Wildlife Habitat Council (WHC) announced the winners of its 2023 WHC Awards at the WHC Conservation Conference in Baltimore, Maryland on June 20-21. The awards honor excellence in corporate conservation, with awardees representing various national and international companies across industries. Freeport-McMoRan, WM and Matador Ranch & Cattle won the top awards, signifying leadership in conservation, and the Employee Engagement Award. The 2023 Gold Program of the Year Award was awarded to Matador ranch & C cattle for its Beaverhead Ranch site in Dillon, Montana, and three project awards recognizing their conservation and education work in Arizona and New Mexico. The WHC has been promoting and certifying ecological stewardship action on corporate lands through partnerships and education for 35 years, and has resulted in more than 1,000 certified programs across 47 states and 28 countries.
description: Wildlife Habitat Council (WHC) announced the winners of its 2023 WHC Awards during the WHC Conservation Conference held in Baltimore, Maryland, on June 20-21.

summary:
Wynn eyes expansion of Everett casino -- including gambling -- on big site across Broadway. Big Night plans to relocate its Memoire nightclub from the casino to the club space in the new building ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ in part to make way for the overhead passageway and to take advantage of the larger venue, newer technology, and outdoor decks.

Big Night partner Ed Kane said he‚Äö√Ñ√¥s been impressed with the creativity that Wynn and Elkus Manfredi Architects have shown in designing the new building.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Whatever way of Broadway you approach it from, you‚Äö√Ñ√¥re not going to miss this building,‚Äö√Ñ√π Kane said. 

Matt Lattanzi, Everett‚Äö√Ñ√¥s planning director, said he estimates the first phase would generate $3.6 million a year in new property taxes (or payments in lieu of taxes, depending on the eventual legal structure). Rival theater operators were worried about the competition, and pointed to a provision in the state‚Äö√Ñ√¥s gaming law that bans event venues with 1,000 to 3,500 seats from being built on casino properties.
description: Wynn Resorts is seeking state approval to expand gaming to a new building it's planning across Broadway from the Encore Boston Harbor Casinos in Everett.

summary: Cummins Inc. has announced plans to invest $1.5 billion in new clean-energy technologies by 2027, rebranding its New Power unit to Accelera. The company is aiming to meet its net-zero carbon emissions goal by 2050 and is facing supply chain challenges due to increased demand for its engines used in trucks and other heavy vehicles. Despite this, Cummins reported a jump of nearly 9% in fourth-quarter sales for its engine segment. Analysts predict that as Cummins seeks to become a global leader in clean engines, an ongoing tight supply chain will be a challenge.
description: Cummins Inc. plans to invest $1.5 billion in new clean-energy technologies by 2027, company executives told Reuters on Wednesday.  The U.S.-based engine maker announced on Wednesday it would change to name of its New Power division to Accelera and continue to offer battery electric and alternative fuel products such as engines, generators and power systems to meet its net-zero carbon emissions goal by 2050.  The Columbus, Indiana-based company, known for its diesel and natural gas engines, has accelerated its push towards clean energy solutions to sell to its industrial and commercial transporation customers as the trucking industry is expected to face tougher greenhouse emissions regulations this year.

summary: Jamie Dimon, the only major bank CEO from the financial crisis still in command, believes that US regulators are likely to overreact in their response to the turmoil that swept through the banking industry in March, leading to the collapse of four regional lenders. Dimon has played a central role in the reaction to the industry‚Äö√Ñ√¥s worst period of tumult in more than a decade, spearheaded an industry lifeline to First Republic Bank and ultimately stepped in to buy the lender last week when those efforts proved insufficient. The KBW Regional Banking Index has dropped 12% since that deal was announced, and JPMorgan‚Äö√Ñ√¥'s shares have climbed this year, and Dimon joined a call with the roughly 230 remaining wealth advisers to pitch them on staying with JPMorgan. He will first have to contend with an exodus of First Republic advisers who left as its troubles mounted this year.
description: JPMorgan‚Äö√Ñ√¥s chief executive officer predicts more rules are coming to an industry already struggling.

summary: Microsoft has announced that state-backed Chinese hackers have been targeting U.S. critical infrastructure and could be laying the technical groundwork for a potential disruption of critical communications between the U.K. and Asia during future crises. The targets include sites in Guam, where the US has a major military presence, and the National Security Agency, the FBI, the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and their counterparts from Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Britain have published a joint advisory sharing technical details on ‚Äö√Ñ√∫the recently discovered cluster of activity‚Äö√Ñ√π Microsoft said the intrusion campaign placed a ‚Äö√Ñ√∫strong emphasis on stealth‚Äö√Ñ√π and sought to blend into normal network activity by hacking small-office network equipment, including routers. The intruders gained initial access through internet-facing Fortiguard devices, which are engineered to use machine-learning to detect malware. Tensions between Washington and Beijing have been on the rise in recent months due to recent tensions between the two countries.
description: Hostile activity in cyberspace has become a hallmark of modern geopolitical rivalry

summary:
FCC will start kicking voice providers out of its robocall database. 

Telecoms slow to adopt anti-robocall measures could soon face stiff punishment in the US. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) now plans to remove seven voice service providers from its Robocall Mitigation Database for failing to comply with required anti-spam efforts, such as implementing STIR/SHAKEN call authentication to prevent spoofing. However, the FCC's move (along with a campaign from state attorneys general) could discourage telecoms that either skimp on anti-robocall defenses or knowingly profit from scammers and telemarketers.
description: FCC will start kicking voice providers out of its robocall database

summary: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has expressed concern about Silicon Valley Bank depositors following the bank's collapse on Friday, but said that investors would not be bailed out. Yellen said she'd been working with regulators to design appropriate policies to address the situation and that she wanted to "emphasize" that US banks were safe and well-capitalized and that Americans can have confidence in the safety and soundness of their bank system. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) took control of SVB Friday after California regulators shut it down when a failed $2.3 billion capital raise sent its stock crashing. The agency protects deposits of up to $250,000, but higher sums are at risk.
description: The Treasury Secretary said regulators were "very aware of the problems" faced by depositors in the failed lender but warned investors won't get bailed out.

summary:
Concession awards mark a reset for Macao casinos. 

To win the permission, the casino companies agreed to invest collectively nearly $15 billion dollars in Macao to achieve government goals of diversifying the local economy beyond gambling and encouraging international tourism. This month, Macao has seen an increase in tourism from mainland China from visitors trying to get an mRNA Covid vaccine. 

A rise in Covid infections around China caused November gaming revenue in Macao to fall 23% from October and plummet 99% from November 2019 pre-pandemic levels, according to government data.
description: The Macao government has awarded 10-year concessions to six casino operators. In return, they have committed to invest nearly $15 billion in the destination.

summary: A clutch of big tech firms, including Amazon.com Inc. and Apple Inc. have told the European Union they meet the requirements to be subject to the bloc's landmark digital antitrust rules, which could have a major impact on how they operate. The seven platforms have notified the EU they meet thresholds to be designated as a so-called gatekeeper, which includes having a sales across the bloc of at least ‚Äö√á¬®7.5 billion ($8.2 billion) or a market capitalization of ‚Äö√á¬®75 billion or more. To qualify, such core platform services will need to have more than 45 million monthly active end-users and more than 10,000 yearly active business users in the bloc. Under the obligations, platforms will face a range of dos and don‚Äö√Ñ√¥ts, including pre-installing certain applications and favoring their own services. They must also allow third-party payment systems on their platforms and permit users to download apps from alternative online stores on their phones.
description: A clutch of big tech firms including Amazon Inc. and Apple Inc. have told the European Union they meet the requirements to be subject to the bloc‚Äö√Ñ√¥s landmark digital antitrust rules, which could have a major impact on how they operate.

summary: Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (GS) is one of the stocks most watched by Zacks.com visitors lately. Over the past month, shares of this investment bank have returned +2.2%, compared to the Zacks S&P 500 composite's +4.9% change. This article looks at some of the factors that might affect the near-term performance of the stock, such as media releases or rumors about a substantial change in a company's business prospects. description: Goldman (GS) has received quite a bit of attention from Zacks users lately. Therefore, it is wise to be aware of the facts that can impact the stock's prospects.

summary: A new ¬¨¬£650m funding package for the UK's life sciences sector has been announced, including a shake-up of planning rules to free up lab space and efforts to encourage pension schemes to invest in emerging science and technology firms. The package includes up to ¬¨¬£250m committed to incentivising pension schemes, scientific efforts to prepare for future health emergencies, and increased the capacity of the UK‚Äö√Ñ√¥s biological data bank. The plan will also see ¬¨¬£121m, made up of new and existing funding, to speed up clinical trials and improve access to real-time data. The government said that the new railway funding was a sign of its ‚Äö√Ñ√∫ongoing commitment‚Äö√Ñ√π to the East-West Rail project between Oxford and Cambridge.
description: It is the latest effort to follow up on the prime minister‚Äö√Ñ√¥s pledge to turn the UK into a ‚Äö√Ñ√≤science superpower‚Äö√Ñ√¥

summary: Lockheed Martin is realigning its space business operations to three lines of business, including Commercial Civil Space, Strategic and Missile Defense System and National Security Space. The rejig comes as simmering geopolitical tensions fuel demand from both the United States and international customers. Lockheed Martin said the changes will bring in greater effectiveness in delivering on customer missions and will support growth and innovation.
description: Lockheed Martin is realigning its space business operations, transitioning from five lines of business to three to enhance speed and effectiveness, the defense contractor said on Thursday.  The rejig comes as simmering geopolitical tensions fuel demand from both the United States and international customers.  The three lines of business include Commercial Civil Space, Strategic and Missile Defense System and National Security Space.

summary: NASA has unveiled two new aircraft projects, the X-66A and the Transonic Truss-Braced Wing, as part of its Sustainable Flight Demonstrator project. The planes are designed to reduce fuel consumption and emissions by up to 30% compared with today‚Äö√Ñ√¥s most efficient aircraft. The first test flight of the full-scale demonstrator is set to take place in 2028 and the goal is for the technology to serve about half of the commercial market through short- to medium-haul single-aisle aircraft. NASA is collaborating with industry partners on new technologies including lighter and more efficient motors, electronics and materials that can help improve fuel efficiency and reduce emissions. The other planes to get a new look are the hybrid electric aircraft that GE Aerospace and magniX are developing as partof NASA‚Äö√Ñ√¥‚Äö√Ñ√¥√î√∏Œ©s Electrified Powertrain Flight Demonstration project.
description: Snazzy new liveries have been revealed for two of NASA‚Äö√Ñ√¥s hottest aircraft projects. These upcoming planes want to be the next generation of sustainable flight ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ and also to look good when doing it.

summary:
U.S. agency panel to review VLSI patent in $2.2 bln Intel case. 

USPTO director Kathi Vidal earlier this month sanctioned the company that sought the review, OpenSky Industries LLC, finding it attempted to extort both Intel and VLSI. 

VLSI said in a previous statement that allowing the proceeding to continue would wrongly reward Intel, which had already lost on other board challenges to the patents.

summary: Intel's stock fell 6% on Wednesday after the chipmaker hosted an investor call to discuss its ‚Äúinternal foundry model‚Äù segment, which makes Intel‚Äôs PC, data center, automotive and other chip design units into customers of its own factories. The segment still generated only $730 million in revenue for the trailing 12-month period ended in March. Intel is working on closing that gap, and expects to announce a major foundry customer for the most advanced process it is developing before the end of the year. Morgan Stanley analyst Joe Moore says a major customer win would be a positive for the story, but also noted the risk that the changes required to build up a foundry business could also cost Intel some competitive edge in its core business.
description: Chip maker shakes up internal structure, but investors still aren‚Äôt satisfied

summary: Xcel Energy, a Minneapolis-based utility, has reported a leak of 400,000 gallons of radioactive water from its Monticello nuclear power plant to state and federal authorities in late November. The company said there was no health and safety risk to the public and that monitoring from over two dozen on-site monitoring wells confirms that the leaked water is fully contained on the plant site and has not been detected beyond the facility or in any local drinking water. The NRC says tritium spills happen from time to time at nuclear plants, but that it has determined that they‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve either remained limited to the plant property or involved such low offsite levels that they didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t affect public health or safety. Xcel Energy is considering building above-ground storage tanks to store the contaminated water it recovers, and is considering options for the treatment, reuse, or final disposal of the collected tritsium and water.
description: While Xcel Energy reported the leak of water containing tritium to state and federal authorities in late November, the spill had not been made public before Thursday.

summary: Walt Disney is considering selling off other traditional TV assets, such as ABC and FX, in an effort to find a strategic partner for its ESPN sports business. summary: Some Democrats are pointing fingers at the U.S. Department of Transportation after a train carrying hazardous materials derailed in East Palestine, Ohio. Lawmakers argue that the crash could have prevented with better regulations and that the Transportation Department should have prioritized safety over profit. Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Cal.) is holding the Transportation department partly responsible for forcing Norfolk Southern, a major transportation company, to prioritize safety over profits. Sen. Sherrod Brown and Sen.-Ohio have called for Congressional inquiry and direct action from Secretary Buttigieg to address the tragedy. Buttigigieg previously said the Transportation Dept. is "constrained by law" due to the Trump administration's 2017 withdrawal of a rule requiring the installation of electronic braking systems on some trains carrying flammable materials.
description: "We need Congressional inquiry and direct action from Secretary Buttigieg," one tweeted.

summary: Norfolk Southern CEO Alan Shaw has defended his company's actions since the derailment of one of its trains in East Palestine, Ohio, and promised the railroad will pay for the cleanup. Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro has charged that Norfolk Southern‚Äö√Ñ√¥s ‚Äö√Ñ√∫corporate greed, incompetence and lack of care for our residents is absolutely unacceptable to me. Shaw said the company has already paid out $6.5 million to citizens living near the site of the derailments and that it is committed to the community and citizens of East Palestine. He also said the railroad has been in agreement with the actions of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and local efforts on the ground since the train derailment. Despite criticism from the governor of Pennsylvania, Shaw said he did not see the press conference where these statements were made and could not respond. He said his company continues to monitor air and water quality and has conducted hundreds of tests with thousands of data points.
description: Norfolk Southern CEO Alan Shaw defended his company's actions since the disaster caused by the derailment of one of its trains in East Palestine, Ohio, and promised the railroad will pay for the cleanup.

summary: The National Transportation Safety Board's preliminary report has revealed that the Norfolk Southern train derailment earlier this month has captivated public attention and drawn partisan ire. Accusations, speculation, conspiracies and finger-pointing have flourished in the information vacuum, leading to speculation and conspiracy theories. Democrats are accusing President Biden of not reacting swiftly enough, while Democrats are pointing at the railroad companies and at the Trump White House for relaxing certain safety regulations around trains and chemicals. The NTSB is conducting fact-finding alongside eight other agencies, unions and companies, and is looking into the response to the accident and other issues. Lawmakers and many inside, or close to, the industry hope the accident will spur regulatory changes.
description: The derailment has turned into something of a Rorschach test for Americans.

summary: Washington lawmakers are considering a bill that would limit the length of freight trains moving through the state, which could reduce the risk of incidents like the East Palestine derailment earlier this month. The bill would cap the amount of a train traveling through Washington with a standard crew at no more than 7,500 feet and if an additional crew member was added to the end of the train to monitor movements, the train could be up to 10,000 feet in length. Union officials say there has been a nationwide trend in recent years toward longer trains, and they say these trains most often run without a railroad worker in a rear car to help spot trouble. Representatives of two major railroads operating in Washington state, BNSF Railway and Union Pacific, testified against the bill during the Tuesday hearing. The measure, if it clears the Legislature and is signed by Gov. Jay Inslee, could face a legal challenge.
description: A bill that cleared the state House Transportation Committee on Thursday would limit the length of trains traveling through WA.

summary: The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has concluded that the Ohio train derailment was ‚Äú100 per cent‚Äô preventable‚Äù during a press conference today. The NTSB determined that the cause of the accident was the result of an overheated wheel bearing on the 23rd car of the 150-car Norfolk Southern train that derailed near East Palestine, Ohio. The cars that breached and caught fire were equipped with plastic hazmat placards that are used to tell rail officials what materials are inside the cargo tankers, which melted due to the heat. The agency also revealed that the wheel bearing‚Äôs high temperature did not trigger defect detectors along the track until it was close to failure. It is also making recommendations for preventing future disasters like the one in East Palestine.
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said the Ohio train derailment was ‚Äú100 per cent ‚Äú preventable during a press conference discussing the causes of the accident.

summary: Crew members on the train that derailed in Ohio earlier this month, unleashing a huge blaze and spreading dangerous chemicals, tried to slow and stop the train after seeing an alert about an overheating wheel bearing. The engineer put the brakes on and the automatic braking system activated, but it was revealed that a wheel bearing had been heating up for a considerable time before the train reached East Palestine, Ohio, near the Pennsylvania state line. The report was issued as the transportation secretary visited the area on Thursday and federal environmental regulators took control of the clean-up, ordering the US railroad company Norfolk Southern to foot the bill.
description: Engineer put the brakes on, the NTSB‚Äôs report says, but a wheel bearing had been heating up for a considerable amount of time

summary: A preliminary National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) report has revealed that a rapidly overheating wheel bearing and an extremely short warning time conspired to send a freight train off the rails in East Palestine, Ohio, earlier this month. The NTSB received a ‚Äúcritical audible alarm message,‚Äù and an engineer did slow and stop the train and emergency brakes kicked in, but the crew didn‚Äôt get the warning until just before dozens of cars derailed. An axle temperature more than 200¬∞F above the surrounding air is considered critical and warrants stopping the affected rail car completely for inspection. Pennsylvania and Ohio officials have promised an investigation, and Norfolk Southern has also announced it will open a health clinic for people with concerns or symptoms and has established a relief fund. Residents were evacuated within a two-mile radius so officials could conduct a ‚Äòcontrolled burn‚Äù of the vinyl chloride. Environmental Protection Agency officials have since deemed the soil, air and surrounding groundwater to be below toxic levels and safe for residents.

summary: The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) has sued Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM) for racial discrimination after nooses were found at one of its facilities in 2020. The EEOC alleged that a Black employee at Exxon's chemical plant in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, found a hangman's noose at his work site in January 2020. Exxon investigated some of these incidents, but not all, and failed to take measures reasonably calculated to end the harassment. Exxon said it disagreed with the EEOC's findings and allegations.

summary: Walmart Chief Financial Officer John David Rainey said that the company expects 65% of its stores to be serviced by automation within three years, but does not anticipate any near-term layoffs. summary:
The National Retail Federation said this month that it expected holiday sales from November to December to increase 6 to 8 percent, which is below the pace of inflation. 

Throughout much of the pandemic, when shoppers were spending freely and supply chain snarls were front of mind for retailers, discounts were offered infrequently. And with shoppers being more discerning about how they spend, many retail executives have said they expect a return this year to the usual kind of holiday deals that were absent from many stores last year. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Last year was just an unbelievable year for any retailer, but especially apparel,‚Äö√Ñ√π said Zachary Warring, an equity analyst at CFRA.

summary:
"The recent earnings calls have only reinforced the familiar and unwelcome theme that corporations did not need to raise their prices so high on struggling families," Kyle Herrig, president of the advocacy organization Accountable.Us, told The New York Times. 

In the U.S., average food prices increased by 11.2% from September 2021 to September 2022. 

The National Retail Foundation says Halloween candy racked up $10.6 billion for 2022, compared to $10.1 billion last year. 

"While the cost of Halloween candy has surged more than 13.1% since last September, the Mars candy bar family become 44% richer during the pandemic increasing their wealth to $32.6 billion," Sanders tweeted.
description: Campaigners accuse corporations of profiting off the suffering of the American people. Inflation, the pandemic, and supply chain issues are the avenues by which multinationals dug deeper into the everyday man's pocket.

With the 1Q23 sale of Con Edison Clean Energy, Con Ed has become a pure-play regulated utility with over 90% of assets at CECONY, and the company purchases and transports gas from as far away as Canada and the Gulf of Mexico. summary: Microsoft services including Teams, Outlook and Xbox Live go down across the world. Multiple Microsoft 365 services went down for thousands of users around the world, prompting the tech giant to investigate the incident affecting several of its products. In an announcement about the outage posted in the early morning (ET time) of January 25th, the company said users were unable to access its services, including Microsoft Teams, Exchange Online, Outlook, SharePoint Online, OneDrive for Business, Microsoft Graph, PowerBi and Microsoft 365 Admin Center. The tech giant admitted that the outage might not be limited to those products, however, and true enough, over a thousand users also reported having problems with accessing Xbox Live on Down Detector.

summary: Delta Air Lines is facing a lawsuit over its $1bn carbon neutrality claim, which plaintiffs allege is ‚Äö√Ñ√∫false and misleading‚Äö√Ñ√π as it relies on offsets that do little to mitigate global heating. The lawsuit alleges that customers would have purchased Delta tickets believing they had no impact on the environment and many would not have bought them without the carbon neutrality claims. It also alleges scientific and journalistic evidence that there are deep flaws with carbon credits from the unregulated voluntary market Delta has purchased for its environmental claims. Delta has not responded to request for comment from the Guardian. The case argues that there is a market premium for green products and that Delta has profited from a misleading environmental claim. A judge will now decide whether or not to decide whether to pursue the case.
description: US airline pledged to go carbon neutral but plaintiffs say it is relying on offsets that do almost nothing to mitigate global heating

summary: Bond market plunge means the low for stocks is not in yet, Bank of America's Hartnett says. Treasury yields in the U.S. surged again Friday, with the 2-year note, which is most sensitive to Federal Reserve rate hikes, jumping 7.4 basis points to 4.2% around noon ET. As consumer and producer prices rise and the Federal Reserve and its global counterparts react, the "new regime of higher inflation means secular view remains cash, commodities, volatility to outperform bonds & stocks," he added. The S & P 500 has fallen more than 4.5%, while the Nasdaq 100, whose tilt toward tech stocks makes it particularly vulnerable to higher rates, also was down more than 4%.
description: Bond market plunge means the low for stocks is not in yet, Bank of America's Hartnett says

summary: Hedge funds are increasingly using more leverage to make wagers on the stock market this year, but are less inclined to bet on the market direction due to heightened macroeconomic uncertainties. Gross exposure, or the sum of long and short positions, reached peak levels for the last one year according to Goldman Sachs' prime services weekly report. However, their long wagers minus short ones, known as net exposure - a measure of directional risk appetite - is close to a year low of 66%, which illustrates that portfolio managers have little bias on overall market direction. Volatility has caught hedge funds off-guard in the beginning of the year, with the S&P 500 going up roughly 9% at its peak in February 2, but trimmed gains to 4% now. Long-short hedge fund Anson Funds, with $1.5 billion in assets under management, is roughly neutral, with shorts and longs matching off. Higher interest rates are forcing investors to make until recently unthinkable calculations, as cash may provide a good return.
description: Hedge funds are increasingly using more leverage to make wagers on the stock market this year, but they remain less inclined to bet on the market direction due to heightened macroeconomic uncertainties.

summary: Leaders of the largest US chipmakers have warned that the US government should study the impact of restrictions on exports to China and pause before implementing new ones. Companies are being forced to curb shipments to their largest market by Washington, which has cited national security concerns about the Asian nation acquiring certain capabilities. The Biden team has been exploring ways to further tighten existing curbs, such as targeting chips made by Nvidia specifically for the China market. The executives argued that while Chinese customers have been forced to buy more chips to do the work of banned products, that hasn't significantly slowed them down.
description: Leaders of the largest US chipmakers told Biden officials this week that the administration should study the impact of restrictions on exports to China and pause before implementing new ones, according to people familiar with their discussions.

summary: Intel's new 12-qubit quantum processor ( or QPU) is set to be made available to select universities and institutions across the US, potentially giving more researchers an opportunity to tinker with quantum computing hardware first hand. The new processor, called Tunnel Falls, is Intel's most advanced silicon spin qubit chip to date and draws upon the company's decades of transistor design and manufacturing expertise. Companies such as Google and IBM are taking different approaches to Intel, creating powerful versions of the technology that are accessed remotely using software rather than distributing the hardware itself. With more qubits produced, Intel can share them with other researchers. This level of sophistication allows them to innovate novel quantum operations and algorithms in the multi-qubits regime and accelerate their learning rate in silicon-based quantum systems.
description: A new quantum processor built on silicon will soon be made available to a select few universities and other institutions across the US, potentially giving more researchers an opportunity to tinker with quantum computing hardware first hand.

FILE PHOTO: The headquarters of U.S. energy exporter and pipeline operator Kinder Morgan Inc. is seen in Houston

(Reuters) - Kinder Morgan Inc reported a 16.4% rise in quarterly profit on Wednesday, as the U.S. pipeline operator transported higher volumes of jet fuel. 

The Texas-based company posted a net income of $576 million, or 25 cents per share, for the third-quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with $495 million, or 22 cents per share, a year earlier.

summary:

The B&P plant was shut early on Friday morning after a contractor was killed in a rail car accident, the people said. 

The Jefferson County Sheriff's Office said deputies were called to B&P Plant shortly after 12 a.m. CDT (5 a.m. GMT) on Friday.

summary: Russian military-linked hackers targeted European military and transport organizations in an apparent spying campaign that went undetected for months as the war in Ukraine raged. summary: Companies embedded in China's manufacturing, construction and export industries are reporting weaker sales, with some warning of further trouble to come. Companies expressed disappointment with Beijing‚Äö√Ñ√¥s stimulus measures and cut their sales outlook for the country into this year. Hotel chain Marriott reported a surge in demand for its rooms in China amid a rebound in domestic travel, adding that it was generating more revenue per room now than in 2019. Meanwhile, recent data showing an unusual drop in consumer prices have raised concerns that the country could be entering a deflationary spiral of progressively weakening demand.

The FDA inspected an Optum Infusion facility in Chandler, Ariz., in March 2022 and found "serious deficiencies in your practices for producing drug products intended or expected to be sterile, which put patients at risk," the FDA wrote in the letter posted publicly on Tuesday. 

Infusion services are part of Optum Rx, one of Optum's three business units. 

Information and technology firm Wolters Kluwer said Optum is "one of the leading home infusion companies in the country with coverage coast to coast."

summary: A deal to rescue one of the biggest suppliers of soybean meal fed to livestock herds around the world is at risk of falling apart due to court delays and Argentina‚Äö√Ñ√¥s worst drought in living memory. The bankruptcy of Vicentin SAIC more than three years ago upended oilseed trading in Argentina, the top exporting nation of meal and of soy oil used in food and biofuels. After a tumultuous default that featured a botched nationalization and accusations of fraud by international lenders, Vicentin finally seemed to have secured its future. Creditors and crop suppliers agreed to restructure $1.3 billion of debt with a consortium led by Glencore Plc-backed Viterra and Bunge Ltd. At stake is the future of a firm whose credit-fueled expansion before its collapse helped it fend off multinationals like Cargill Inc. The delay also comes at a time when Bunge and Vicentin are in merger talks, and their biggest overlap is Argentine soybean crushing. If the judge continues to put off a decision, a downward spiral would ensue.

summary:
"As we bring on more electric vehicles, as more customers move to Colorado and the Denver metro area, that requires us to make sure that the grid is able to handle that new load," said Robert Kenney, President of Xcel Energy Colorado. He says the money will be used to strengthen the power grid, repair and replace infrastructure, and create new programs. 

It's not the first time in the last two years rates have gone up, the average residential electric customer saw an 8.61% increase in March of last year, a 6.44% increase in April of this year, and a 2.9% increase in their natural gas bill just last month. 

Kenney said he knows the rate increases can be hard on customers, and Xcel offers payment plans and bill assistance for those who need it.

summary: A look at the cause and effect of high energy prices in Colorado, with Bill Levis, a volunteer advocate for the AARP and a former head of what's now known as the Office of Consumer Council, discussing the conflict between the Public Service Company of Colorado and its subsidiary of Xcel Energy, a large corporation. Levis believes that people who are facing rapidly rising bills are facing not only higher base rates but more surcharges, which have caused more pain. He also blames actions like the closing of the Comanche III coal fired power plant in Pueblo, which was originally scheduled to go decades into the future, but will now shut down in 2030.Levis does not hold back on Xcel and its rate hike requests, arguing that Xcel as a Fortune 300 company should assume some of the cost.
description: There's a lot of blame to go around for the skyrocketing heating bills residents in Colorado are having to pay, and there's a lot of finger-pointing, too.

summary: Minnesota has settled its lawsuit against e-cigarette maker Juul Labs and tobacco giant Altria for $60.5 million, which is significantly higher per capita than any other state that sued Juul over youth vaping and marketing practices. The settlement was the first and still the only one of thousands of cases nationwide against the e-cigarettes maker to reach trial. If Minnesota had settled on the same terms as the six states and the District of Columbia, it would have gotten about $30 million, or as little as $15 million if it had accepted the terms most other states did. Most of the other cases have settled, including dozens with other states and U.S. territories, and the settlement specifically prohibits Juul from marketing to children and young adults in Minnesota. Minnesota will also get documents specific to the state for a total of 10 million documents that researchers and journalists can pore through, and will get about $43 million after litigation costs and attorney's fees.
description: Democratic Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison on Wednesday announced a $60.5 million settlement with e-cigarette company Juul and tobacco giant Altria.

summary: The Wall Street Journal and Molson Coors have both reported that Bud Light sales may not be recovering in the United States, with retailers already reallocating space to other brands during shelf resets that take place in the spring. A report from the WSJ has more on the numbers, which remain not good for the Bud Light brand, and a media blitz campaign. summary: The Department of Defense has launched an investigation into why Boeing staff members were allowed to work on the current and future Air Force Ones with expired security clearances. The issue involves about 250 Boeing employees, who initially had the "Yankee White" clearances, but in some cases, the clearances had expired years ago. The affected employees had maintained their underlying top-secret clearances but tighter credentials are also required for presidential security. The Air Force said the operations on the future Air force One fleet were not halted over the documentation issue, and there was no impact on the aircraft's schedule. The first of the two new planes is set to be delivered by September 2027.

summary: A new study from Fortune has found that mass layoffs are terrible for shareholders, but there are 10 cost saving options that work better. The research suggests that if a business avoids "a vicious cycle of employee turnover" driven by overworked staff and low morale, any cost savings from layoffs will likely be lost. The other companies can take these options instead of mass layoffs, including voluntary reduction in hours, internal redeployment, reducing executive compensation, voluntary leave of absence, a hiring freeze, and sabbaticals.

summary:
Goldman Sachs Group Inc (GS.N) plans to cut the year-end bonuses for its traders, Bloomberg News reported on Friday, as the Wall Street giant looks to trim costs. 

Executives at the investment bank's global markets division were informed that the compensation pool would be slashed by a low double-digit percentage, the report said, citing people with knowledge of the discussions. 

Investment banks have been hit by a plunge in dealmaking activity this year as choppy markets and aggressive rate hikes by the Federal Reserve have forced lenders to pull back from financing large deals. 

Earlier this year, Goldman Sachs had announced a restructuring and scaled back ambitions for its loss-making consumer unit.

Reporting by Anirban Chakroborti in Bengaluru; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila

Bank of America and Morgan Stanley will report their results on July 18, followed by Goldman Sachs on July 19. Looking ahead, banks may pull back on lending in preparation for new rules that could require them to hold more capital. summary: Homebuilders are winning the housing recovery by offering buyers what they want: lower interest rates. The nation's three largest homebuilders, D.R. Horton, Lennar and Pulte, have seen 52-week highs for their stock prices this month due to price cuts and mortgage buydowns. Builders pay money up front to cut the cost of a mortgage for a period as short as two years or as long as 30 years, and are offering low-cost deals cheaper than the average 6%-plus 30-year rate. The most common mortgage buydown puts rates in the mid-to-high 4% range, though some drop as low as the 3% range. Prices are settling down and builders are gaining an upper hand by addressing buyers' top concern.
description: Builders are reporting strong sales thanks, in part, to mortgage buydowns.

summary:
Royal Caribbean beats quarterly revenue estimates. 

(Reuters) - Royal Caribbean Group beat third-quarter revenue estimates on Thursday, benefiting from bookings and strong onboard spending as cruise travel rebounds after a pandemic-led pause. 

The cruise operator's revenue rose to $2.99 billion for the third quarter from $456.96 million a year earlier, compared with estimates of $2.97 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.

summary: Life Sciences and medical diagnostics company Danaher (DHR) delivered a first-quarter earnings beat Tuesday, even as its lowered outlook sent shares of the Club holding tumbling. Revenue for the period ended March 31 declined nearly 7% year-over-year, but outpaced analysts' estimates of $7.03 billion. When excluding the impact of Covid testing sales and sales of products that support COVID-19 related vaccines and therapeutics, Danaher realized base-business core sales growth of 6%. The revised outlook was impacted by the ongoing destocking of bioprocessing inventories, and management is forecasting base business core-revenue growth to be in the mid-single-digit percent range for the second quarter. The adjusted operating profit margin is expected to be roughly 26%, while management expects a similar dynamic for the full year 2023.

summary: Pfizer has warned that hospital supplies of dozens of drug products could be disrupted after a tornado damaged its production and storage plant in Rocky Mount, N.C. The risk of new shortages comes as the United States is struggling to obtain sufficient supplies of products such as antibiotics, cardiac medication and chemotherapy drugs. The FDA does not anticipate ‚Äö√Ñ√∫any immediate significant impacts on supply‚Äö√Ñ√π due to the damage to the plant, and the FDA has begun looking for additional sources and asking manufacturers to prepare to ramp up production for drugs that are in or risk being in shortage. Drug shortages in the United states are lasting longer than average, according to a March report published by the Democratic majority on the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs.
description: A tornado damaged Pfizer's Rocky Mount, N.C., plant, which could disrupt hospitals' access to some drugs, including those containing morphine and lidocaine.

summary: United Parcel Service UPS and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters are holding a strike if contract negotiations with the company fail to yield a new agreement. Results from the strike authorization vote are expected Friday. The coming UPS contract covers about 330,000 employees including delivery drivers and package handlers in a likely five-year deal that will go through 2028. Subcommittees between the union and UPS have reached tentative agreements on several issues, including on operating priorities, the use of technology and in-vehicle cameras. Other issues still on the bargaining table include higher pay for part-timers and a second category of weekend drivers, which Teamsters want to do away with. UPS has said that a two-tier system of drivers allows UPS to use lower-paid workers to deliver packages on weekends, curbing delivery costs.

summary:
And if earnings estimates go up for a company, the fair value for its stock goes up. This is why empirical research shows a strong correlation between trends in earnings estimate revisions and near-term stock price movements. Cardinal is expected to post earnings of $1.48 per share for the current quarter, representing a year-over-year change of +2.1%. Comparing the current value of a company's valuation multiples, such as its price-to-earnings (P/E), price-to-sales (P/S), and price-to-cash flow (P/CF), to its own historical values helps ascertain whether its stock is fairly valued, overvalued, or undervalued, whereas comparing the company relative to its peers on these parameters gives a good sense of how reasonable its stock price is.

The Zacks Value Style Score (part of the Zacks Style Scores system), which pays close attention to both traditional and unconventional valuation metrics to grade stocks from A to F (an An is better than a B; a B is better than a C; and so on), is pretty helpful in identifying whether a stock is overvalued, rightly valued, or temporarily undervalued.

summary:
BlackRock creates Transition Capital unit to tap climate opportunities -memo. 

LONDON, Oct 17 (Reuters) - BlackRock (BLK.N), the world's biggest asset manager, has set up a unit called Transition Capital to invest in opportunities linked to the global shift to a low-carbon economy, a memo to staff seen by Reuters showed. 

BlackRock, which manages around $8 trillion in assets, said Transition Capital would work with portfolio managers and BlackRock's capital markets team to find and back "proprietary transition-focused opportunities" across asset classes and geographies. 

The group would also work with BlackRock colleagues to develop new investment strategies and funds, and help deepen the company's research in the area, the memo said.
description: BlackRock , the world's biggest asset manager, has set up a unit called Transition Capital to invest in opportunities linked to the global shift to a low-carbon economy, a memo to staff seen by Reuters showed.

summary: A lawsuit has been filed against PulteGroup, a residential homebuilding company founded in Michigan and now based in Georgia, alleging that a supervisor at the company brought noose to staff meeting and discriminated against three Black employees. Idus Hartsfield, a customer care manager in the warranty department, attended the "noose meeting" in November 2019 and complained to human resources that the incident "made him highly uncomfortable" but the lawsuit claims nothing was done to address it. The third plaintiff, Richard Turnbow, was allegedly "humiliated" in front of colleagues by the same supervisor for not arriving to a training meeting at least 15 minutes early and was ordered to collect trash around the office. The plaintiffs are demanding a trial by jury and seeking at least $25,000 in damages.

summary:
"Headwinds from foreign exchange shifted significantly in the last 90 days as the trend of US dollar strengthening has accelerated," Nike's finance chief Matthew Friend said. 

At the same time overall inventories rose by 44% to $9.7bn as the amount of goods in transit increased due to supply chain issues. 

"Higher inflation is definitely driving up costs and reducing margins and discouraging consumers, especially now on splashing on highly discretionary items," Hianyang Chan from consultancy Euromonitor International told the BBC. 

Rival sportwear maker Under Armour and major US retailers like Target have have also offered heavy discounts as their inventories rose in recent months.
description: Nike feels squeeze from strong dollar and discounts

The official responsible for New York City‚Äö√Ñ√¥s public pension funds is pressing BlackRock to recommit to achieving net zero emissions across its investment portfolio.

Procter & Gamble Bets Inflation Won't Push Shoppers to Trade Down. 

Inflation is testing Americans‚Äö√Ñ√¥ loyalty to Procter & Gamble biggest brands, but the maker of Tide detergent, Pampers diapers and Gillette razors is betting it can persuade shoppers to keep paying up.

summary: A federal judge has ruled that Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. and Eli Lilly & Co. must defend a racketeering lawsuit against third-party payers by marketing the Actos diabetes drug without disclosing its association with the risk of bladder cancer. The ruling was certified by US District Judge John Holcomb, who appointed Painters and Allied Trades District Council 82 Health Care Fund as the class representative. Lilly has said it intends to appeal the ruling, while the companies have denied the allegations over years of litigation. The case is the first pharmaceutical class to be certified under the federal civil Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act.
description: A federal judge ruled Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. and Eli Lilly & Co. must defend a racketeering lawsuit claiming they defrauded third-party payers by marketing the Actos diabetes drug without disclosing its association with the risk of bladder cancer.

Saks unveils stylish plan for Bond-like casino at flagship Fifth Avenue store. 

‚Äö√Ñ√∫The casino at Saks will attract an affluent global tourist and not prey on people who shouldn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t be in casinos,‚Äö√Ñ√π Baker said. 

‚Äö√Ñ√∫We have been quietly working with community groups including Broadway theaters, retailers and [elected officials] and we have a lot of support for a different type of casino in New York City,‚Äö√Ñ√π Baker said. 

He estimates that the Saks casino could be developed within a year as opposed to competitors who are proposing new developments that could take many years to complete.

summary:
Lawmakers bash Southwest over flight cancellations. 

Lawmakers are hammering Southwest Airlines over its spate of flight cancellations in recent days after a cold front blew in freezing temperatures and snow across broad swaths of the country during the holidays. 

While several airlines faced high levels of cancellations, Southwest canceled at least 70% of its flights Monday due to the weather and a reported system meltdown. 

The cancellations have also caught the eye of the Biden administration, with President Joe Biden saying the "Administration is working to ensure airlines are held accountable" and the Transportation Department saying it is "concerned by Southwest's unacceptable rate of cancellations and delays & reports of lack of prompt customer service" and will " examine whether cancellations were controllable and if Southwest is complying with its customer service plan."

Southwest spokesperson Jay McVay Monday said the direction of the storm played a role in the airline having a disproportionate number of cancellations.

"It's just the fact that this one started West swept east and impacted almost every single one of our largest airports that put us in a position where we struggled to recover, and we struggled to get our flight crews and airplanes where they needed to be," McVay said from Houston's William P. Hobby Airport.
description: Lawmakers are hammering Southwest over its spate of flight cancellations in recent days.

summary:
The US has no regulation that requires financial compensation for delayed flights . Additionally, Buttigieg launched a billion-dollar Reconnecting Communities program that aims to use money from the federal infrastructure act to cut through red lines and connect economically segregated neighborhoods.



Buttigieg has called for more federal regulation of the airline industry, calling the recent meltdown at Southwest that resulted in over 17,000 flight cancellations ‚Äö√Ñ√∫unacceptable,‚Äö√Ñ√π but critics argued he could be more aggressive at holding airline executives accountable. After Southwest promoted multiple executives implicated in the holiday-season cancelations this week, the director of the American Economic Liberties Project Matt Stoller tweeted that the airline was ‚Äö√Ñ√∫just mocking Pete Buttigieg.‚Äö√Ñ√π



Buttigieg has also expressed support for legislation introduced in November 2021 by senator Richard Blumenthal (D-CA) to create a bill of rights for airline passengers that would provide additional consumer protections. The bill has yet to progress from the committee stage.

The Biden administration proposed tougher rules to tackle flight tickets‚Äö√Ñ√¥ hidden fees in September, but regulation in other areas of the airline industry remains scant.
description: More than 6,000 flights were delayed across the country, affecting almost every airline

summary:
Study: If 20% of your diet is these foods, you're at risk of faster cognitive decline. Compared to people who ate the least amount of ultraprocessed foods, those who consumed the most experienced a 28% faster rate of global cognitive decline and a 25% faster rate of executive function decline. 

Frozen dinners, other ‚Äö√Ñ√≤ultraprocessed‚Äö√Ñ√¥ foods linked to risk of early death, study says ‚Äö√Ñ√∫While this is a study of association, not designed to prove cause and effect, there are a number or elements to fortify the proposition that some acceleration in cognitive decay may be attributed to ultraprocessed foods,‚Äö√Ñ√π Dr. David Katz, a specialist in preventive and lifestyle medicine and nutrition, told CNN. While short of proof, this is robust enough that we should conclude ultraprocessed foods are probably bad for our brains.‚Äö√Ñ√π
