summary:
A care provider has been ordered to pay $521,905 in back pay to its employees, after the Department of Labor found it had engaged in "wage theft" after it "willfully denied" overtime pay."

Phoenix-based Urgent Home Care Inc. was found to have broken the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), after an investigation by the department's Wage and Hours Division.

The back pay order was given by the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona, which also imposed a fine of $24,222 for repeat violations. 

In a statement, Wage and Hour Division District Director Eric Murray, said: "Urgent Home Care has again been found violating the rights of workers who provide essential services to people in need. 

"The court's order and the outcome of our investigation send the clear message that the U.S. Department of Labor will use its enforcement powers to recover workers' hard-earned wages and hold those who deliberately engage in wage theft accountable."

Urgent Home Care Inc. was found to have committed similar rule breaches during a separate investigation in 2016.

Under the court order, Urgent Home Care is also banned from taking retaliatory action against any employees who raised complaints and must avoid further breaches of FLSA regulations.

Murray said that companies that don't follow the rules are likely to have trouble holding on to workers, commenting: "As employers continue to struggle to find the people they need to fill open positions, those who fail to respect workers' rights will find it harder to retain and recruit employees than employers who do." 

In a separate case this week, the Department of Labor fined equipment manufacturer Caterpillar Inc. $145,027, after an employee died on June 2 at the company's foundry in Mapleton, Illinois.
description: Urgent Home Care Inc. was fined $521,905 by a court in Arizona.

Food and beverage companies such as PepsiCo are under pressure to raise prices to pass off higher costs for everything from raw materials, transportation and labor.

summary:
The automaker path to autonomous cars has changed. 

After this week's seismic collapse of leading autonomous driving startup Argo AI, it's tempting to think self-driving cars will never materialize. 
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ Instead of shooting for the moon ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ cars that fully drive themselves in all conditions ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ many automakers are adopting an interim strategy of equipping cars with partial automation to handle the worst aspects of driving.
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ It's easier and cheaper, and they can do that soon, with many of the same sensors and software they've been developing for fully autonomous cars. 
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ "What's happening here is that the companies with the best product have pulled ahead and are accelerating," Cruise CEO Kyle Vogt told GM investors the day before Argo's shutdown was announced.

summary: A new study has found that seven in 10 van fleet drivers prefer the electric version of their favoured van over the petrol or diesel alternative, with just 15 percent of drivers preferring petrol and diesel-powered models. Demand for electric vans is on the rise with January 2023 seeing a significant increase in demand for them, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT). New registrations of battery electric vehicle vans rose to 993 units last month, compared to 647 units in January 2022. According to the SMMT, registrations for BEV vans grew by 31.2 percent throughout 2022, with its UK market outlook forecasting a 60.7 percent rise in 2023. Electric car charging network needs to be 'prioritised' before 2030, and the Ford Transit Custom and Ford Transit are the two most popular models in 2022. Electric versions of the most popular vans are available, including the Ford e-transit, Citroen e-Berlingo and the Mercedes-Benz e-Vito.
description: A majority of van drivers are looking to turn their backs on polluting petrol and diesel vehicles and move over to electric, according to new data.

summary: Ford Motor Co. is under investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration after two complaints that the vehicles behaved erratically after undergoing repairs. The problem stems from the fractures in the rear axle mounting bolt, which can result in the drive shaft disconnecting. Ford claims to have remediated the issue after updating the vehicle software, but two owners of repaired cars filed complaints with the National highway Traffic Safety Authority about losing control over their cars. No injuries were reported in their cases, although one car struck a utility pole.
description: Ford‚Äö√Ñ√¥s recall of almost 300,000 Explorer SUV‚Äö√Ñ√¥s is under investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

summary: Seaweed, a natural carbon sink and commonly used in foods and supplements, is becoming increasingly popular in Maine due to climate change. The U.S. seaweed market is expected to grow to over $5 billion over the next six years, and 90% of seaweed is currently grown overseas. Seaweed is being used in cosmetics, clothing and bio-plastics, and is an economic driver for the state of Maine. Dozens of Maine lobstermen are now becoming kelp farmers as a way to diversify and diversify. An international "Seagriculture" conference was held in Portland, Maine this week, where dozens of seaweeds producers discussed potential new opportunities. Procter & Gamble is attending the conference to better understand how new materials such as seaweed could work as a future material for use in their products and packaging.
description: Dozens of Maine lobstermen are now becoming kelp farmers as a way to diversify as warming oceans move the catch north.

summary:
Dr Matt Derry, who is leading the project, said in a statement: 'Simply building new data centers without improving data storage technologies is not a viable solution. 

According to a report from the International Data Corporation (IDC), 'the consequence of this increasing reliance on data will be a never-ending expansion in the size of the Global Datasphere.'

The report shows the estimated zettabytes (ZB), a measure of digital storage capacity, in 2019 was just 45ZB, but by 2025 that is set to increase to 175ZB.

One zettabyte is equivalent to a trillion gigabytes.

'If you were able to store the entire Global Datasphere on DVDs, then you would have a stack of single layer Blu-ray discs that could get you to the moon 23 times or circle Earth 222 times,' IDC shared in the report. Dr Amit Kumar Sarkar, who recently joined the Aston University team, said: 'We will be exploiting advanced polymer chemistry as a pathway to increase the amount of data that can be housed on storage media. 

If you enjoyed this article...

Scientists store data inside DNA that could last MILLIONS of years

Also, the breakthrough that could mean your phone will never run out of space again: Microsoft sets DNA strand storage record
description: Scientists at Aston University are scrambling to find a solution in the next three years to  accommodate the 'mind-blowing amount' of data that will need to be stored.

summary: U.S. banks are offering bonuses to customers who open new accounts or deposit money on a regular basis, following the recent failures of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and Signature Bank. Capital One Financial Corp. is offering a $100 bonus for opening a new savings account and keeping more than $10,000 in it for 90 days, while Discover Financial Services and LendingClub are offering similar perks. Banks are also trying to retain customers by employing other techniques such as explaining to customers the rules around deposit insurance, offering different products or emphasizing ties to local communities. Smaller banks, which were most strained by the recent crisis, have been able to stem the exodus of deposits for now, according to weekly from the Federal Reserve. The Independent Community Bankers of America said some of its members had actually gained deposits in recent weeks as consumers and small businesses sought out banks with strong ties to their local markets.
description: For months, consumers have clamored for banks to pay out more for deposits as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates.

summary: Walmart and Kroger are the most popular grocery chains in the Richmond area, with 23.3% of the market share as of last year. summary: The battle over whether grocery giants Kroger and Albertsons should be allowed to combine is heating up. Both challenged the companies on their actions, including Kroger's $1 billion in share buybacks announced last year and plans to pay dividends to shareholders as well as previous deals, such as Albertsons' acquisition of Safeway. Their concerns ranged from the potential loss of their pension plans to higher food prices to job losses. Union members also railed against the private equity firms that will benefit from the proposed $4 per share special dividend for Albertsons shareholders announced in conjunction with the deal.
description: Leaders of the two companies faced questions about how the deal could shake up the competitive landscape ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ and the prices consumers pay at the store.

summary: Nvidia shares were down more than 1% in afternoon trading on Wednesday following a report that the Biden administration is considering new restrictions on the sale of artificial intelligence semiconductors to China. The potential export controls would prevent Nvidia and other chip makers from shipping chips used to create powerful AI systems to China without first obtaining a license. The timing of any potential ban on AI chip exports is still uncertain, as chip makers including Intel and Nvidia lobby the administration to ease any new restrictions or drop them altogether. The new action could heighten the tensions between the U.S. and China, even as Washington has taken steps to stabilize the bilateral relations in recent weeks by arranging meetings between senior officials. China has also responded by blacklisted Micron Technology as a national security risk and prevented Chinese companies from buying its products.
description: Potential new restrictions on the sale of artificial intelligence semiconductors to China could come with a hefty long-term cost for the American chip industry‚Äö√Ñ√Æand another setback for U.S. relations with Beijing.

summary: Tyson Foods Inc. is closing four chicken processing plants in an effort to lower costs. The company is shifting production to other facilities and will halt operations at the four plants in the first two quarters of fiscal 2024. Tyson recently posted a surprise loss in its second quarter and cut its sales forecast due to the cost of plant closures and layoffs. It also reported its fiscal third-quarter financial results on Monday. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect revenue of $53.74 billion and Tyson still anticipates fiscal 2023 revenue of up to $54 billion. This article may have altered it prior to publication to ensure that it meets our editorial standards.
description: The company said Monday that the plants being closed in North Little Rock, Arkansas; Corydon, Indiana; Dexter, Missouri and Noel, Missouri.

summary: Home builders are capitalizing on the recent fall in mortgage rates and the shortage of existing homes for sale this spring, as demand for newly built homes has increased. The S&P Homebuilders Select Industry stock index is up 17% so far this year, outpacing the S&Ps 500‚Äö√Ñ√¥s 8.6% gain. New single-family home sales are bouncing back with supply tight in the existing-home market, and mortgage rates have come down from the 20-year highs they hit in the fall. Builders ramped up activity during the pandemic-driven housing boom, but they struggled to keep up with demand due to labor shortages and supply-chain problems. This year, the improved backdrop helped new single- family home sales rise 9.6%. Builders were aggressive to cut prices and offer incentives to attract buyers by making purchases more affordable.
description: A recent fall in mortgage rates relieves a source of industry pressure.

summary:
But petroleum derivatives also are used as material for many products in everyday use, including plastics, chemicals, and rubber products ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ colloquially referred to as the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Big 3‚Äö√Ñ√π because of their high dependence on oil.

Therefore, any increase in oil prices is also reflected in the production costs of these products ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ price hikes that companies can then pass on to consumers to protect their own profit margins. 

Lululemon, the high-end athleisure company, increased prices across 10% of its product line in June, citing high materials costs. 

And Clorox raised consumer prices four separate times in 2022, an effort to offset higher materials prices and account for the higher costs of shipping and manufacturing. 

And the price hikes from added materials costs only add to the other forms of cost pressures driven by higher oil prices and higher energy prices in general.
description: They show no signs of abating as 2023 goes on.

summary: Cleveland, Ohio, has informed residents that their drinking water is safe amid concerns over the environmental consequences from the derailment of a train hauling chemicals in the northeastern part of the state. Cleveland Water notified residents that its drinking water comes from Lake Erie, which is ‚Äö√Ñ√∫separate from the Ohio River and its watershed.‚Äö√Ñ√π East Palestine residents are also asking for financial support after being forced to evacuate from the area, and transport company Norfolk Southern Railway has announced it will launch a $1 million charitable fund initiative to help the East Palestine community. summary: On Feb. 6, an apocalyptic plume of gas rose over the village of East Palestine, Ohio, blotting out the sky. The National Transportation Safety Board has opened an investigation into the train derailment, while a federal lawsuit seeking class-action status has been filed by several East Palestine residents. Government officials told evacuated residents of the Ohio-Pennsylvania area on Feb. 8 that they could safely return to their homes, based on air quality samples. In 2012, a train crashed in Paulsboro, spilling 23,000 gallons of vinyl chloride , the same chemical involved in the East Palestine spill .
description: US railway company Norfolk Southern is giving $25,000 to East Palestine, Ohio, where a train derailment has precipitated an environmental and health crisis.

summary: Following backlash from consumers, executives at U.S. companies have cut their mentions of ESG (environmental, social, and corporate governance) and DEI (diversity, equity, and inclusion) on earnings calls by 31% from the same period last year. This is the fifth straight quarter of year-over-year plunges, and there is evidence that the backlash is having an effect. However, some analysts believe that companies are still hushing down on initiatives such as sustainability and greenhouse-gas emissions. Target's stock plummeted 19.98% from its high in March due to the loss of $12 billion in market value to rest at $61.85 billion in the wake of a consumer boycott triggered by its LGBTQ merchandise.

summary:
Verizon‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Profit Falls 23% as Price Increases Slow Growth. 

Verizon said retail customers are balking at the monthly rate increases it instituted over the summer. 

Verizon Inc. said its earnings slipped by nearly a fourth in the third quarter as retail customers balked at its recent price increases. 

The telecommunications giant said Friday that its consumer business lost 189,000 wireless retail postpaid connections, attributing the drop to higher customer churn that followed monthly rate increases it instituted over the summer.
description: The telecommunications giant‚Äö√Ñ√¥s consumer unit loses 189,000 wireless retail customers following recent prices rises.

summary: Burberry has announced the appointment of Klaus Bierbrauer as chief supply chain and industrial officer, effective immediately. Nike also announced changes to its leadership team, with its longtime executive vice president, chief communications officer, Nigel Powell, retiring after 24 years with the company. KeJuan Wilkins, vice president of enterprise communications for Nike, will lead all global corporate, consumer and employee communications for the sportswear giant. Todd Dalhausser, previously brand president of Altra, has been appointed to the position of global brand president, Dickies. Jan Van Mossevelde, president of Icebreaker, is assuming additional responsibilities for the Smartwool brand as part of VF‚Äö√Ñ√¥s focus on capturing future opportunities for strategic and operational synergies. Claire Bergkamp, Textile Exchange CEO and longtime partner of Aii, has joined the organization's board of directors.
description: Longtime Nike communications officer Nigel Powell retires after 20-plus years while VF Corp. shifts various key leaders.

summary: The $8.2 billion deal between Bunge and Glencore-owned Viterra could create a trading group worth about $34 billion that would be big enough to take on industry giants such as Cargill and Archer Daniels Midland. Bunge's profile surpasses most of its competitors in the U.S. agricultural-products industry, and news sentiment surrounding the company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s ESG profile has been positive. The potential scale of the merged company could peak the interest of antitrust regulators, with the combined business likely to dominate the global oilseed-processing, and corn- and soybean-exporting markets. Mining giant Glencore would have a 15% stake in the combined company, giving the Swiss-based miner a significant stake in what would be a key player in the agricultural-product industry. This diversification could appeal to Glencore shareholders, as the metals-and-mining industry comes under continued scrutiny over the environmental and social implications of extractive operations.
description: Bunge‚Äö√Ñ√¥s acquisition of Viterra could expand the company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s reach in North American crops and bolster its ESG profile.

summary: Halliburton reported mixed second-quarter results before the bell Wednesday, with total revenue rising 14% year over year to $5.8 billion. Earnings per share (EPS) of 77 cents exceeded the adjusted Refinitiv estimate of 75 cents, while strong execution in both operating divisions allowed profit margins and earnings to exceed expectations. Management reiterated that growing free cash flow is a top priority, and they expect over 50% of it to be "returned to shareholders this year." Despite the disappointing results, Halliburton shares dropped 3% on Wednesday after a strong run over the past month that we trimmed into on Friday for a small gain. Management expects exploration and production spending to grow this year and into the future, and full-year free flow growth of 30% to 40% over last year's level. With 2022 freeCash flow coming in at $1.43 million, this forecast amounts to about $1,93 million at the midpoint.
description: On the post-earnings call, Halliburton management reiterated that growing free cash flow is a top priority for the oilfield services giant.

summary: Nike Well Collective is the latest brand to launch a new strategy to incorporate wellness in its global offering, focusing on 5 pillars: movement, mindfulness, nutrition, rest and connection. The brand is now more holistic, aiming to link fitness to mindfulness and wellbeing more directly with this new strategic vision. The launch of the Nike Well Collective will provide resources, inspiration and methods to promote physical wellbeing which encompasses movement, rest, breathing. Tools will be developed by 1,000 new fitness trainers globally and a team of medical professionals and researchers who will provide actionable ways to improve sleep, body image and other factors that play a role in holistic wellness. Research shows that consumers don't actually want a single solution or platform to cater to all facets of their wellness needs and priorities. Nike clearly has the credentials to play within this space given that sports and movement play an unquestionable role in one‚Äö√Ñ√¥s physical and mental wellbeing, but in trying to be everything to wellness enthusiasts, it might struggle to find its audience or drive engagement with its existing customers.
description: Nike is launching Nike Well Collective in efforts to provide additional health and wellness experiences to its customers.

The Competition and Markets Authority said it provisionally found no competition concerns in the deal between specialist health care tech and software companies which provide services to Britain's NHS.

summary: Chemicals giant Dow Inc on Thursday missed Wall Street estimates for fourth-quarter results, hurt by higher energy costs, weaker demand and supply chain disruptions, and said it would cut about 2,000 jobs, or about 5% of its workforce. Production costs have risen in recent quarters following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, while China's Covid-led lockdowns have squeezed demand for Dow, which sells its chemicals to industries ranging from automobiles and food packaging to electronics that are also facing supply chain disruptions. Net sales in the fourth quarter fell 17% to $11.86 billion, pressured by customer destocking, missing the average estimate of $12 billion, according to Refinitiv IBES data. Quarterly sales volume fell 8%, hurt by 18% decline in Europe, the Middle East, Africa, and India (EMEAI) and destocking in building & construction and consumer durables end-markets in the U.S. and Canada.
description: Materials science company Dow is cutting about 2,000 jobs, or roughly 5% of its global workforce, in an effort to reach $1 billion in cost savings this year.

summary: 3M is leveraging its history in the auto industry to get a slice of the fast-growing electrification market. Auto electrification is now a $500 million business for 3M after sales leapt 30% last year, and as more electric vehicles are sold, fewer combustion models will be made, making 3M's pivot toward the EV market all the more important. Demand for electric vehicles in Europe and China is driving growth, with 200 million on the road by the end of the decade. 3M has released a new thermal barrier material for battery cells, which is one small solution to mitigate the big problem of "thermal acceleration events" and increased battery efficiency can also reduce the need for cobalt, an expensive and rare mineral. With its first generation of electric vehicles, Tesla has set the bar for massive touch-screen displays that replaced the traditional touch-obs that replaced traditional touch screens.
description: Auto electrification is a $500 million business for the Maplewood-based company, which seeks to lower consumer costs of electric cars.

summary:
Louisiana State Treasurer John Schroder announced on Wednesday that the Pelican State would divest nearly $800 million in funds from asset management company BlackRock. 

In a letter to BlackRock CEO Larry Fink, the official explained that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing violates Louisiana state law on fiduciary duties, which require ‚Äö√Ñ√∫a sole focus on financial returns for the beneficiaries of state funds.‚Äö√Ñ√π Indeed, Fink wrote in his most recent letter to chief executives that ‚Äö√Ñ√∫climate risk is investment risk.‚Äö√Ñ√π 

Amid state governments‚Äö√Ñ√¥ moves to spurn ESG investment, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is developing requirements that would force companies to report the material impact climate change presents to operations, the impact of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫climate-related events‚Äö√Ñ√π such as severe weather on transaction activities, and risk management processes used to mitigate climate risk.
description: Louisiana Becomes Latest State To Reject Woke Investing, Will Divest $800 Million From BlackRock

summary: Tyson Foods is cutting 262 non-relocation workers from offices in Dakota Dunes, South Dakota, Chicago and Downers Grove, Illinois, to its headquarters in Springdale, Arkansas. The company is seeking to cut costs in the face of easing demand from cash-strapped consumers and high costs for basics like cattle. July 31 will be the last day of work for most of the 262 employees opting not to relocate, with those being terminated held titles including senior vice president of pork and head of sales for pork and beef. Tyson last month posted a surprise second-quarter loss and cut its full-year revenue forecast amid slowing consumer demand.
description: Tyson Foods Inc. will terminate about 262 employees in South Dakota who chose not to relocate to its headquarters in Arkansas, showing widespread resistance to the move, the company confirmed Friday.

summary: A group of Republican state officials have sent a letter to BlackRock's mutual fund directors demanding information from them about any potential conflicts of interest. The letter criticizes the firm's efforts to mitigate climate change and integrate ESG standards into the firm, and accuses them of using client assets to advance an ideological agenda. The state financial officers also criticized BlackRock for its ties to China and for its involvement in mutual funds and other investment products for Chinese consumers. BlackRock denies any impropriety and said the trustees would respond to the letter.
description: A group of Republican state officials has fired another salvo in a war against BlackRock over its embrace of environmental, social, and governance standards and investment in China, this time demanding information from the firm's mutual fund directors.

summary:
China slaps sanctions on U.S. CEOs over Taiwan arms sale. 

STORY: Beijing on Friday imposed economic sanctions on executives at two American aerospace and defense firms, Boeing Defense and Raytheon, moves a foreign ministry spokeswoman said were retaliation for weapons sales to Taiwan. In order to safeguard China's sovereignty and security interests, the Chinese government has decided to sanction those who are involved in this sale of weapons - Chairman and CEO of Raytheon Technologies, (Gregory) Hayes, and Boeing Defense President and CEO, (Ted) Colbert." 

The sanctions targeting Boeing Defense President and CEO Ted Colbert and Raytheon Technologies boss Gregory Hayes come after the U.S. State Department earlier this month approved the sale of systems made by the defense firms to Taiwan.
description: China slaps sanctions on U.S. CEOs over Taiwan arms sale

summary:
Boeing documentary shows a company and system primed for disaster. 

It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s impossible for anyone following Boeing‚Äö√Ñ√¥s trajectory to watch the compelling documentary ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Flight/Risk‚Äö√Ñ√π without concluding that the Jack Welch-inspired management of the company has a body count.

Specifically, the 346 people who perished in two 737 MAX crashes in 2018 and 2019. Most egregiously, the FAA allowed Boeing to self-certify the MAX and ignored a high risk of future crashes. 

Boeing pushed the FAA in 2014 to relax the safety standards for the MAX to avoid having to upgrade the system that alerts the crew if something goes wrong during flight.
description: Boeing documentary shows a company and system primed for disaster

summary:
Boeing is a leading company in the air refueling aircraft market. Such abounding growth prospects are expected to aid Boeing‚Äö√Ñ√¥s position in the air refueling aircraft market. Moreover, with the major defense budget increase worldwide to modernize and upgrade the defense structure, as well as increased air missions, the air refueling aircraft market is expected to witness a northward trend. summary: KBR, Inc. has won a $24-million contract from the 94th Army Air and Missile Defense Command (94th AAMDC). The win aligns with KBR's focus on expanding operations within the Indo-Pacific region in support of the U.S. strategic goals in the region. KBR has been providing mission-critical logistics, operations and prepositioned stock services to various nations across the world for more than 25 years. The total backlog (including award options) was $20.89 billion compared with $19.76 billion at 2021-end, and the Sustainable Technology Solutions segment accounted for $4.9 billion of the total backlog. QPR Services Inc. reported better-than-expected results for first-quarter 2023, while ACM anticipates generating 8% organic NSR growth (4% for actual NSR). The company expects adjusted earnings and revenues of $3.55-$3.75, which indicates a 10% improvement from the fiscal 2022 reported levels.
description: KBR expands its base operations' support services in the Indo-Pacific region with a $24-million contract.

summary: A trio of antitrust advocates have launched the Responsible Online Commerce Coalition, a coalition of small businesses and large brands that will push for the US government to pare back Amazon‚Äö√Ñ√¥s power over the online shopping ecosystem. The coalition will focus on small sellers, while other companies have already committed to joining. The group will advocate for competitive pricing for seller commissions, limiting the amount of counterfeit products circulating online, offering sellers the freedom to offer their products at a discount and ensuring search results are fair and non-discriminatory. The creation comes as governments around the world are considering cracking down on Amazon. The US Federal Trade Commission is investigating Amazon's potentially anti-competitive behavior.
description: Businesses that rely on Amazon Inc. to sell their goods are beginning to band together against the e-commerce retail behemoth.

summary: Brands are joining the chorus of content producers and creators demanding more data-sharing from streamers, as well as an industry effort to standardize measurement of brand films. Blue-chip brands like Pepsi and Saint Laurent are among the brands demanding more audience data from streaming platforms. Companies are struggling to tell if their investment is paying off due to the lack of data, and brand stakeholders are hoping to loosen up with data sharing to spur more brand spending on films. Brand Storytelling, an organization that holds a widely attended festival for brand content alongside the Sundance Film Festival, is spearheading an initiative to come up with standardized best practices, measurement, and ROI that will help marketers assess the impact of brands' content.
description: Procter & Gamble, REI, and more brands backing Hollywood-style entertainment want streamers to share data to measure the reach and impact of their content.

summary: American Airlines Group Inc on Wednesday forecast first-quarter profit below market expectations, pushing its shares more than 8% lower and weighed on other major U.S. airlines. The airline industry has been able to survive the broader economic slowdown in the United States, thanks to constrained airline capacity due to shortages of aircraft and spare parts, and American said it expects total revenue per available seat mile to be up about 25.5% in the first quarter from a year earlier. However, on an adjusted basis, it forecast quarterly profit per share between 1 and 5 cents compared to a previous forecast of near break-even and analysts' expectation of 6 cents. The lower forecast came despite the carrier slightly lowering the jet fuel price guidance to $3.32 per gallon from its prior outlook.
description: American Airlines first-quarter profit below market expectations, joining rival United Airlines to signal a hit from persistently high labor and fuel costs.

summary: Supply chain security, a strong U.S. dollar and government incentives are among the reasons for the uptick, said Brian Belski, chief investment strategist at BMO Capital Markets. Announcements by companies in the third quarter jumped 20% since the second quarter and 150% versus 2019, UBS analyst Chris Snyder wrote in a November note. Some 87% of U.S. executives with operations in China plan to move production out of the country and about 70% of those are considering the U.S. for relaxation, according to a survey by UBS Evidence Lab. It includes more than $52 billion for U.S. companies producing computer chips and billions more in tax credits.
description: The ramp up in reshoring by companies, including those committing to building in the U.S., is just getting started, experts believe.

summary: The RSA Conference (RSAC) in San Francisco this week highlighted the importance of artificial intelligence (AI) as a potential tool for security and identity management. This year, RSA Security CEO Rohit Ghai highlighted the need for AI to strengthen zero-trust architectures and identity Management, while AT&T released its Cybersecurity Insights Report at RSAC. Meanwhile, Fortinet used RSAC to speak to a CyberRatings security effectiveness score for its FortiGate 600F series next-generation firewall, while Palo Alto Networks used it to announce an expansion of its 42-month cloud-based security unit. Finally, Blackberry published a threat intelligence report to arm security operations teams with timely access to threats, actionable insights and the ability to prevent, hunt and respond to threats quickly.
description: Vice President, Security, Carriers and Enterprise Networking, Will Townsend, shares his insights into what he found most compelling at RSA Conference 2023.

summary: A new report from Google Cloud's cyber intelligence arm Mandiant has revealed a growing threat from alleged cybercriminals supporting North Korea. The group is believed to be supporting the North Korean government's primary foreign intelligence service through espionage targeted at foreign government agencies, private companies and educational institutions around the world. The report found that APT43 engages in spear-phishing campaigns that aim to harvest private user information and engage in stealing and laundering cryptocurrency. The director of Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Jennifer Easterly has expressed concern about the threat and called for a full ban on the Chinese-owned social media giant TikTok, which has seized on short-form video-sharing on a massive scale. CISA is also working to establish cybersecurity reporting norms and standards to help victims of cybercrime and strengthen vulnerable institutions.
description: A new report details alleged funding mechanism of North Korean cyber espionage.

summary: WestRock, a packaging giant in Sandy Springs, Atlanta, is reportedly close to a $20 billion international merger with Dublin-based Smurfit Kappa. The Wall Street Journal reported that the deal could be announced next week if talks don't fall apart. Both companies have made multiple acquisitions in recent years, and the Atlanta area is a logistics hub and is home to numerous companies that make packaging materials. Most paper and packaging corporations have seen demand decline this year following explosive growth in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. WestRock reported $21.3 billion in sales during the 2022 fiscal year and has a market capitalization of $8.2 billion.
description: One of metro Atlanta‚Äö√Ñ√¥s largest companies is reportedly close to an international merger that could create a $20 billion paper and packaging behemoth.

summary: RBC Capital Markets analyst Deane Dray highlighted nVent, a provider of cooling systems used in datacenters that was spun off from Pentair in 2018, as an unexpected beneficiary of the artificial intelligence boom. RBC expects demand for liquid cooling to potentially reach a total addressable market of $2 to $3 billion and grow at a compounded annual rate of 25% as AI demand grows. Other potential winners include Digital Realty Trust and digital infrastructure company Equinix. Dray also highlighted Dover, Eaton and Wesco as names with exposure to liquid cooling.
description: Greater datacenter demand could benefit this stock over the long run

summary: California's annual carbon emissions auction of greenhouse gas permits fetched $35.20 per ton last week, raising $1.2 billion for the state's greenhouse gas reduction fund. Companies are spooked by the state‚Äö√Ñ√¥s plan to eventually tighten its emissions cap, which they expect to reach its goal of a 40 percent emission reduction by 2030. The Air Resources Board, which runs quarterly auctions for high-emitting companies, has announced that it will be modeling scenarios for a tighter allowance budget and just-for-kicks goals of a 55 percent reduction. Prices on the spot market have been trading at just over $35 per ton since then, as companies expect prices to eventually shoot up when the supply tightens, and companies are anticipating California will eventually link its market with Washington state, which just started its program. The primary way that emission reductions have been achieved so far is through regulatory programs and performance standards, and prices would need to be a lot higher to entice industry to change their practices instead of buying permits.
description: High-emitting companies paid more than they ever have for state carbon allowances last week. It won‚Äö√Ñ√¥t do much for emission reductions.

summary:
The Twin Cities need more housing, and downtown Minneapolis office towers are becoming emptier. What they're saying: Towers built in the 1950s and later were constructed with larger floors thanks to the introduction of fluorescent lighting and air conditioning, said Meghan Elliott, founding principal of New History, a historic building reuse consulting firm based in Minneapolis. The intrigue: Apartment developers and the lenders who finance their projects need to get creative on how they use the middle of the buildings, Elliott said. ‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ While many of downtown Minneapolis' office towers aren't historic now, they could be soon.
‚Äö√Ñ¬¢ "The rule of thumb on a building being historically designated is 50 years or older," Elliott said.
description: Minneapolis' modern office buildings are hard to convert into apartments.

summary: For competition officials across the United States and Europe, many of whom were burned by failing to sufficiently scrutinize previous game-changing tech deals like Facebook‚Äö√Ñ√¥s $1 billion acquisition of Instagram more than a decade ago, the corporate world simply fails to accept a new reality that tougher enforcement is here. London's blocking of Microsoft's $69 billion deal for the video-gaming giant Activision marks a dark day when uncertainty from antitrust regulators, in how they approached such megadeals, undermined companies‚Äö√Ñ√¥ ability to do what they do best: make money. The European Union and U.K. have warned that existing Big Tech players are gobbling up new parts of the digital landscape, often via acquisitions of nascent competitors that have yet to break into the mainstream. Meanwhile, the EU's officials have until May 22 to either block or approve the deal, and Microsoft is challenging the FTC‚Äö√Ñ√πs lawsuit and has said it will appeal it.
description: There‚Äö√Ñ√¥s a new uncertainty about getting tech‚Äö√Ñ√¥s megadeals past skeptical regulators.

summary:
A souring economic picture is already casting shadows on financial performance of commercial property giant CBRE Inc.

The Dallas-based real estate firm reported a 19% decline in core earnings per share for the most recent quarter. 

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Lower third quarter core earnings-per-share reflected a sharp deterioration in the macro environment, particularly with regard to capital availability for transactions,‚Äö√Ñ√π said Bob Sulentic, CBRE president and chief executive officer. But CBRE‚Äö√Ñ√¥s sales revenue dipped by 16%, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫with a notable decline in activity in September following relatively flat performance in July and August. And the company‚Äö√Ñ√¥s revenue from mortgage origination dropped 28% as ‚Äö√Ñ√∫most debt capital sources significantly curtailed their lending as the quarter progressed.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Even with weakening income from some sectors, CBRE reported more than $7.5 billion in revenues for the quarter, compared with $6.8 billion in third quarter 2021.

summary:
We just saw earlier today with Target which plunged after slashing its guidance and warning of a sharp slowing in consumer spending in recent weeks, and moments ago we saw that in an entirely different industry, when chipmaking giant Micron Technology said it was slashing capex by reducing DRAM and NAND wafer starts by about 20% versus 4Q 2022 in response to market conditions. 

The company said that it is "these reductions will be made across all technology nodes where Micron has meaningful output" and added that Micron is also working toward additional capex cuts. In calendar 2023, Micron now expects its year-on-year bit supply growth to be negative for DRAM, and in the single-digit percentage range for NAND.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Micron is taking bold and aggressive steps to reduce bit supply growth to limit the size of our inventory. The chipmaker elaborates that recently, "the market outlook for calendar 2023 has weakened" and adds that "in order to significantly improve total inventory in the supply chain, Micron believes that in calendar 2023, year-on-year DRAM bit supply will need to shrink and NAND bit supply growth will need to be significantly lower than previous estimates."

The news hammered MU stock, which dropped as much as 6% before rebounding modestly.



Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices were among semiconductor companies that were dragged lower in sympathy; both NVDA and AMD slid as much as -2.4% as realization the coming recession will further cripple demand across the semis space.

      Tyler Durden
Wed, 11/16/2022 - 09:27

summary:
Trucking companies are pinning hopes for a rebound in freight demand on the second half of this year, saying their retailer customers expect to resume restocking after winding down inventories over recent months.

Carrier executives say they are hearing from their shipping customers that they expect to return to a more normal ordering cycle this year and start moving bigger volumes closer to the fall shopping season following volatile retail spending and distribution in 2022 that left them overstocked.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫The general consensus, almost unanimous, from customers that have given us feedback about their inventories has been that by the time they get through the spring, things are caught up,‚Äö√Ñ√π David Jackson, president and chief executive of trucking giant Knight-Swift Transportation Holdings Inc., said on an investor conference call Jan. 26. Freight movement on U.S. roads, rails and through ports has slowed since the middle of 2022, cutting off a boom in shipping during the pandemic as retailers rushed goods through logistics networks to meet strong consumer demand. The falloff began as U.S. consumers shifted their spending last year toward services rather than goods and rising inflation dampened demand at stores, leaving big retailers including Walmart Inc., Target Corp. and Kohl‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Corp. with warehouses swamped with unsold merchandise.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Trucking is definitely down right now,‚Äö√Ñ√π said Tom Nightingale, CEO of AFS Logistics, a Shreveport, La.-based logistics operator. ‚Äö√Ñ√π

J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc., a bellwether for the freight market with operations across trucking and rail services, said freight-related revenue excluding fuel surcharges fell 3% in the fourth quarter.

Shelley Simpson, president of Lowell, Ark.-based J.B. Hunt, said its retail customers have told the carrier that a pullback in orders is ‚Äö√Ñ√∫largely an inventory correction‚Äö√Ñ√π driven by the shift in consumer buying patterns rather than broader weakness in the economy.

She said on a Jan. 18 earnings conference call that the company ‚Äö√Ñ√∫has good signals‚Äö√Ñ√π from shipping customers that they plan to pick up their ordering in the second quarter.

David Parker, CEO of Covenant Logistics Group Inc., a truckload carrier based in Chattanooga, Tenn., said he expects consumers to pick up their shopping when warmer weather brings people outdoors.
description: Freight executives say their customers have told them they plan bigger orders closer to the fall shopping season.

summary:
Louisiana top court asked to weigh scope of environmental whistleblower law. 

(Reuters) - A U.S. appeals court on Friday asked Louisiana's top state court to decide whether a law protecting environmental whistleblowers from retaliation extends to workers who report illegal activity as part of their regular job duties. 

A three-judge 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel certified questions to the Louisiana Supreme Court in a case accusing natural gas company Targa Resources of firing an employee for refusing to comply with his manager's directive to dilute water samples used to test compliance with environmental standards. 

"Resolution of this appeal turns on contested, unsettled issues of Louisiana state law that implicate matters of critical concern to the state," the panel said in an unsigned opinion.

summary: A bipartisan Senate bill is set to introduce a bill that would require ticketing merchants to disclose up front full ticket prices, including fees, for concerts, sporting events and other large gatherings. The measure follows the reintroduction of the Junk Fee Prevention Act earlier this month, and comes as lawmakers wage a broader battle against ticket sellers. If the measure passes, primary and secondary market ticket sellers will be required to disclose the entire ticket price, including itemized fees, at the beginning of a transaction and prior to ticket selection. The Federal Trade Commission also released a rulemaking proceeding on Nov. 8 to probe unfair acts or practices related to ticketing and other various fees.
description: The TICKET Act from Sens. Cantwell and Cruz outlines a comprehensive series of requirements for primary and secondary ticketing vendors to disclose fees.

summary: Discover Financial Services (DFS) is set to begin tracking purchases at gun retailers in April, making it the first among its peers to publicly give a date for moving ahead with the initiative. The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) approved in September the launch of a dedicated code for gun retailers, and Discover Financial Services said it will include the new code in its next policy and product update to merchants and payment partners in April. Visa announced Saturday its plans to separately categorize gun shop sales, joining Mastercard and American Express, which have already said they would categorize purchases at firearm stores.
description: The post Another Credit Card Company To Begin Tracking Gun Sales In April ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ 57 Million Impacted By The Change appeared first on The Gateway Pundit.

summary: A bipartisan push in Washington is pushing a bill targeting credit card fees, which would require big banks to allow at least one network that isn't Visa or Mastercard to be used for their cards. Nearly 2,000 retailers, platforms and small businesses are urging lawmakers to pass the bill, which could come by year-end. The bill would require banks with assets over $100 billion to provide customers with a choice of at least two different payment networks to process credit card transactions. Major credit card processing networks like Visa, Mastercard, Discover and Capital One say the bill will actually hurt consumers by diminishing popular credit card rewards programs and lessening fraud protections. There are indications that larger platforms and retailers are funding efforts to block this bill, with 26 organizations having mentioned the Credit Card Competition Act by name in their 2023 first-quarter lobbying reports.
description: Bipartisan support for the Credit Card Competition Act has surged since it was introduced last year.

summary: Corporate programs and government policies are helping companies with less than stellar credit ratings to sign long-term deals for wind and solar power in the U.S. and Europe. Investors and bankers are concerned that companies with lower credit profiles won't be able to pay through the entirety of a renewable-energy contract, which usually spans 10 or more years, and it is among the top reasons such agreements fall through. The European Union is now looking to address the issue as part of a broader overhaul to the power market, with the state considering state guarantees and guarantees for PPA buyers, reducing the financial costs associated with defaulting on large-scale renewable energy contracts. Companies such as Microsoft are also taking the lead in easing these credit concerns.
description: Businesses with less than stellar credit ratings are struggling to sign long-term deals for wind and solar power in the U.S. and Europe. Corporate programs and government policies are stepping in to help buyers priced out of the market to cut greenhouse-gas emissions across supply chains.

summary: Microsoft's shares all fell on Wednesday as analysts noted the company's entry into the cybersecurity market. Shares of Zscaler and Palo Alto both slid as much as 7.4%, while Cloudflare shares fell as little as 6.5%. Microsoft's Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Private Access products are in the preview stage, with no pricing details available. Over time, they could strengthen Microsoft's campaign to make security one of its top categories, as older areas such as Windows recede. Analysts at Jefferies, with a buy rating on Microsoft stock, said the move could have "potential longer term ramifications". However, they said gaining meaningful market share in SSE could prove more difficult than in other parts of security due to a lack of structural tie-ins with Microsoft software.
description: Microsoft has grown its security business to over $20 billion per year, and the new effort might help the software maker reach $100 billion by 2030.

summary: Morgan Stanley has responded to requests from U.S. regulators regarding its block-trading practices. description: Morgan Stanley said on Friday it was cooperating with U.S. regulators and responding to their requests on investigations into the firm's block-trading practices. summary: A new piece of research from Bank of America's lead food analyst Bryan Spillane has revealed that the formal consumption of food at a table is heading toward being as outdated as Bing pre-ChatGPT. BofA estimates that the U.S. snacking industry, led by powerhouse names such as PepsiCo, and Hershey, clocked in a staggering $151 billion in sales last year. Snacks accounted for 29% of total packaged food sales in 2022, and Hostess Brands CEO Andy Callahan said that indulgent snacking is growing faster than snacking overall. summary: Australian shoppers are noticing that products bought at their local supermarket are shrinking while the price stays the same, and this is happening around the world. Shrinkflation is when brands start selling less for more by reducing the size of their products but keeping the price the same. In Australia, sizes are decreasing across the board for everything from household products to snacks, with Glad Wrap's bulk option shrank by 25% and Cadbury chocolate has been reduced to 180g. Other brands like Kellogg's and Weet-Bix have also seen their value slashed, with Crunchy Nut hiked its price by 57% after losing 30g in 2022.
description: Neal Chauhan , 28, a shrinkflation expert and founder of Toy Soldier Marketing , began compiling lists of the worst examples of 'shrinkflation' he's found.

summary: Target CEO Brian Cornell said on Wednesday that the retailer is experiencing a rise in "violent" incidents at its stores, resulting in hundreds of millions a year in losses. The increase in incidents comes as other stores across the U.S. are struggling to cope with similar issues, with Whole Foods temporarily closing one of its flagship stores in San Francisco due to concerns that crime in the area is endangering its staff. Cornell forecast that theft would reduce Target's profitability by more than $500 million this year when compared with the prior year. However, some analysts expressed skepticism over whether retail theft, also known as "shrink" by the industry, is as big of an issue as Cornell portrayed it. Consumers are paring back spending amid economic headwinds and Target may be struggling with its own issues.
description: Organized retail crime is impacting Target and other retailers, and shoppers can be in "harm's way," CEO Brian Cornell said.

summary: Lawmakers from the House Select Committee on Competition with China met with Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Co. to discuss the US's dependence on Chinese supply chains. The US is still dependent on China for the critical minerals required to make batteries, and some experts estimate that an independent supply chain remains years away. Representatives from the panel said that by adjusting policies, the US can ‚Äö√Ñ√∫dominate the next generation of battery technology‚Äö√Ñ√π and that there are limits right now in terms of suppliers that auto manufacturers can use.
description: The US needs to make up ground lost to Chinese battery makers and dominate the next generation of the technology, a bipartisan group of lawmakers said after meeting the chief executives of Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Co. in Detroit.

summary: Ford Motor Company is recalling 870,000 newer models of its popular F-150 truck due to the issue of wire chafing, which can cause an increased risk of a crash. The issue affects certain F- 150 trucks from 2021 through 2023 model years that have single exhaust systems. Ford has received 918 warranty claims and three field reports due to wire chaffing, with 19 of those having the brakes activate while the truck was being driven. To correct the problem, dealerships will inspect the rear wiring harness and replace them if needed. GM has recalled 1.5 million vehicles over 2 different issues, including faulty Takata air bag inflators, and Ford has advised drivers to park outside as brake lights can cause fire.
description: More than 900 warranty claims have been filed related to the problem causing the brakes to turn on.

summary: Baker Hughes Co (BKR.O) and HIF Global (HIF Global) are partnering to develop technology for direct air capture (DAC) of carbon dioxide with synthetic fuel maker Mosaic Materials to accelerate DAC deployment at commercial scale. The partnership is expected to accelerate production of synthetic fuel, or eFuel, of which is produced by combining carbon dioxide extracted from the atmosphere with hydrogen and can be used in existing vehicles without any modifications. HIF has an eFuel facility in Chile and it expects to begin construction of another at Texas in 2024. Energy companies like Occidental Petroleum Corp. are increasing investments on DAC technology as a way to help combat global warming.
description: Oilfield services provider Baker Hughes Co said on Tuesday it would develop technology for direct air capture (DAC) of carbon dioxide with synthetic fuel maker HIF Global.

summary: US President Joe Biden has met with several large companies, including Ticketmaster parent Live Nation, and SeatGeek, to discuss ending surprise "junk fees" after pressure from the Biden administration. The White House said in advance of the meeting that Live Nation and Seat Geek had committed to show all fees up front for ticket purchases. Airbnb in December began including all fees in the final price after calls from the White House to do so. The issue reached a boiling point in November when customers were faced with exorbitantly high prices for Taylor Swift's Eras tour tickets. The National Economic Council director Lael Brainard said more companies are heeding the president's call so that Americans know what they're paying for up front and can save money as a result.
description: Live Nation and SeatGeek agreed in advance of a meeting with President Biden to commit to show all fees up front for ticket purchases.

summary: Cardinal Health Inc (CAH.N) raised its annual profit forecast on May 4 after beating Wall Street estimates for the third quarter, due to demand for specialty medicines in a post-pandemic market. The pharmaceutical unit logged a 23% jump in quarterly profit, driven by higher generic drug distribution and specialty drug demand, while the drug distributor expects its medical segment to see an about 50% drop in annual profit due to lower volumes and pricing. The company now expects a full-year profit growth of 10.5% to 12%, compared with its earlier forecast of 4% to 6.5%. Total sales came in at $50.5 billion, beating analysts' average estimate of $49.71 billion. Excluding one-off items, the company earned a profit of $1.74 per share.
description: Cardinal Health Inc raised its annual profit forecast on Thursday after the drug distributor beat Wall Street estimates for the third quarter, as demand for specialty medicines in a post-pandemic market boosted sales at its pharmaceuticals unit.

summary: A recent survey from management consulting firm Gartner finds that only about half of job candidates say they trust the organizations they apply to. This could result in fewer accepted job offers and shorter retention among new hires. The survey also finds that early-career employees are more likely to trust an organization when current employees are involved in hiring, and that recruiters can become a ‚Äö√Ñ√∫point of risk‚Äö√Ñ√π if they withdraw from a position after accepting an offer due to a negative interaction with a recruiter. Finally, the report recommends that HR leaders equip recruiters with the right tools or training to exemplify why top applicants should accept a job offer.
description: Trust has become all the more important to recruiting and retaining new hires, according to a recent report from management consulting firm Gartner.

summary: Albertsons households had the highest median weekly spending on groceries, at around $185. summary: Cardinal Health (NYSE: CAH) has announced plans to build a new distribution center in the Greenville, South Carolina, area to support its at-Home Solutions business, a market-leading home healthcare medical supplies provider. summary: U.S. households have been whittling down their savings and taking on increasing amounts of debt, putting many in a weaker position to weather an economic downturn. The events are likely to cause banks to tighten up their lending, putting added pressure on already strained consumers to pull back on spending and trigger layoffs at companies facing declining sales. Consumers have largely been able to keep increasing their spending, while retail sales declined slightly in February compared to January. Meanwhile, the amount of debt Americans are carrying has soared, and credit card balances increased by $61 billion to a record high of $986 billion in the last quarter of 2022. The percentage of credit card holders carrying debt from month to month has increased to 46%, up from 39% a year ago. Economists are watching the job market in part because consumers have kept up their spending habits, while businesses are looking to borrow money to finance a balance or carry a balance card or buy a car or car loan on their credit cards.

summary: The Royal Caribbean Group is renewing its support for OceanScope, a "satellites of the sea" oceanic data collection program conducted by NASA, NOAA, and the University of Miami. The cruise line said the partnership has helped revolutionize what scientists know about ocean temperatures and is impacting ocean climate strategy around the world, including how governments can best predict and respond to climate events. OceanScope has played a critical role in providing vital and valuable open-source data for scientists through access to oceanographic and meteorological instruments onboard four Royal Caribbean Gropu ships, and Royal Caribbean plans to add these instruments to additional ships.

summary: An essay based on a conversation with Gary Thomas, the senior traveling corporate executive chef for Royal Caribbean, who oversees the meals across all 26 ships and shares why they'll never take prime ribs off the menu. Thomas had never seen a cruise ship before he went to work as a chef on Oasis of the Seas. He was always curious about cruises and whether the cooking standards were similar to kitchens on land, and after 15 years working in specialty restaurants, he decided to take the job. He is based in Liverpool and spends most of his day on calls and answering emails. As an executive chef, he is responsible for feeding guests and crew alike and does inspections with executive chefs, culinary managers, and hotel leaders.

summary: Kinder Morgan shuts west Texas plant used for enhanced oil recovery. Feb 1 (Reuters) - Kinder Morgan (KMI.N) on Wednesday said it had shut a carbon dioxide treatment facility in west Texas used for enhanced oil recovery production following a third-party power outage and equipment failure. The plant is associated with Kinder Morgan's SACROC business in the Permian Basin, which produces some 50,000 barrels of oil per day via enhanced oil recovery, a technique that injects carbon dioxide underground to force more oil out. The company also sells carbon dioxide to third parties.

summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is preparing to open a formal Notice of Inquiry into the impact of internet data caps on consumers. The regulator will also consider "taking action" to ensure that data caps don't harm competition or impact access to broadband services. The FCC currently has just four members, as the Senate refused to confirm President Biden's first nominee, Gigi Sohn, and she subsequently withdrew her name for consideration. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The entire real estate life cycle is changing in many new, interesting, different ways, and we are applying any and all kinds of technology to make it interesting, unlock efficiencies and deliver outcomes for our clients,‚Äö√Ñ√π Dav‚àö¬© said. 

While virtual reality won‚Äö√Ñ√¥t replace CBRE employees‚Äö√Ñ√¥ home offices and physical offices, it could help teams from around the world collaborate without ever having to hop on an airplane.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫We‚Äö√Ñ√¥re a pretty sizable team in global locations,‚Äö√Ñ√π Dav‚àö¬© said. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫If everybody needed to be in a common space, then there is an opportunity for us to be in common space without actually traveling and contributing to all those carbon emissions.‚Äö√Ñ√π

The demo shows off an example of what an onboarding experience in VR could look like. On a podcast in August, he called purchasing land in the metaverse using a traditional real estate model ‚Äö√Ñ√∫the dumbest s--- ever‚Äö√Ñ√π because there are unlimited volumes of it that can be created.

Nishant Batra, chief strategy and technology officer for telecommunications giant Nokia, said on a recent trip to North Texas that metaverse technology could replace smartphones as the primary form of communication by the end of this decade.

Batra pointed to several current and potential different uses of virtual reality and simulations in industries from aerospace to manufacturing, mining and infrastructure engineering.

summary: Chipotle and Domino's customers are beginning to cut back on fast-food orders due to high fees and high costs. McDonald's CEO noted that customers were starting to resist higher burger prices, while Chipotle Mexican Grill and Dominos Pizza have reported that customers are opting instead for carryout to save on costs. Data provider Black Box Intelligence said delivery sales across all the eateries it tracks only advanced 2.1% in the first quarter from a year ago, and this is the fourth consecutive quarter of slowing growth. Consumers are starting to notice higher food costs plus delivery fees, in addition to tips, have made delivery too expensive. Meanwhile, McDonald's recently said consumers resist higher burgers prices and are less likely to add extras to their orders.
description:

summary: CBRE has appointed the exclusive leasing agency for Stamford Plaza, a four-building, 1 million-square-foot office campus conveniently located alongside Interstate-95 and a short walk from the Stamford Transportation Center. The plaza features the Terrace Caf‚àö¬©, a 130-seat restaurant designed by Meaghan Apfel‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Carnelian Studio and operated by Guckenheimer, an award-winning international catering firm. The campus amenities include a state-of-the-art fitness center, teleconferencing centers, shuttles and car service to the train, ATM, car wash and dry-cleaning services. In 2019, the ownership executed a significant capital improvements campaign at the campus which included new entranceways and lobbies for Three Stamford Plaza and Four Stamford.
description: Stamford Plaza is home to firms ranging from asset managers and financial services to life sciences, consumer product and media companies.

summary: CBRE Group, Inc. has secured the top spot in commercial real estate investment sales globally in 2022, according to MSCI Real Assets rankings. This marks the 12th consecutive year of the company securing the top position, with a 23.4% market share across all property types on a global basis. This is a massive 740-basis-point lead over the closest competitor. CBRE's broad range of real estate products and services, and the extensive knowledge of domestic real estate markets helped the company retain its solid growth momentum, as well as diversification across asset types, business lines, client types and geographies. However, macroeconomic uncertainty and its adverse impacts on commercial real Estate transactions are major headwinds for the company in the near term due to global political tension and interest rate hikes. Some better-ranked stocks from the broader real estate sector are FirstService Corporation FSV and Henderson Land Development Company Limited HLDCY, each carrying a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) at present.
description: CBRE benefits from the diversification across asset types, business lines, client types and geographies, and the expansion of its resilient business in recent years.

summary:
Walgreens to seek certification to dispense abortion pill. 

Walgreens Boots Alliance plans to apply for certification to dispense medication that can induce abortions, after a federal rule change Tuesday expanding the ways patients can get the pills.

More than half of U.S. abortions are now done with pills rather than surgery, according to the Guttmacher Institute, a research group that supports abortion rights. Since that U.S. Supreme Court ruling, abortion providers in Illinois, where abortion remains legal, say they‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve seen an unprecedented number of out-of-state patients.
